This vulnerability is being actively exploited in the wild to specifically target Japanese organizations 
The content of the emails vary depending on the business interest of the targeted recipient 's organization $NUM$ however $NUM$ all are about recent political events associated with Japan 
Often such exploitation attempts crash and then relaunch the document viewer to open $HEX$ clean document in order to trick users into believing it is legitimate 
In this particular attack $NUM$ opening the document and dropping the payload are done without crashing Ichitaro and $NUM$ as such $NUM$ users have no visual indications as to what is really happening in the background 
As Security Response previously discussed $NUM$ unpatched vulnerabilities being exploited is nothing new for Ichitaro

Symantec has named this attack campaign CloudyOmega 
However $NUM$ some of the files exploit software vulnerabilities $NUM$ and the aforementioned vulnerability in Ichitaro software is only $NUM$ of them

Each Emdivi variant has $HEX$ unique version number and belongs to $NUM$ of $NUM$ types $NUM$ Type S and Type T 
The unique version number is not only $HEX$ clear sign that Emdivi is systematically managed $NUM$ but it also acts as an encryption key 
Both Emdivi Type S and Type T share the following functionality $NUM$ Type T is primarily used in Operation CloudyOmega $NUM$ has been in constant development since the campaign was first launched in $NUM$ $NUM$ and is written in the $HEX$ programing language

Almost all websites used as $HEX$ $NUM$ $HEX$ servers are compromised Japanese websites ranging from sites belonging to small businesses to personal blogs 
We discovered that $NUM$ out of the $NUM$ compromised websites $NUM$ spread across $NUM$ IP addresses $NUM$ are hosted on $HEX$ single cloud-hosting service based in Japan 
The compromised sites are hosted on various pieces of web server software $NUM$ such as Apache and Microsoft Internet Information Services $NUM$ IIS $NUM$ $NUM$ and are on different website platforms 
This indicates that the sites were not compromised through $HEX$ vulnerability in $HEX$ single software product or website platform

Repressive nation-states have long monitored telecommunica- tions to keep tabs on political dissent 
The Internet and online social networks $NUM$ however $NUM$ pose novel technical challenges to this practice $NUM$ even as they open up new domains for surveil- lance 
We analyze an extensive collection of suspicious files and links targeting activists $NUM$ opposition members $NUM$ and non- governmental organizations in the Middle East over the past several years 
We find that these artifacts reflect efforts to at- tack targets $NUM$ devices for the purposes of eavesdropping $NUM$ stealing information $NUM$ and/or unmasking anonymous users 
We describe attack campaigns we have observed in Bahrain $NUM$ Syria $NUM$ and the United Arab Emirates $NUM$ investigating attackers $NUM$ tools $NUM$ and tech- niques 
In addition to off-the-shelf remote access trojans and the use of third-party IP-tracking services $NUM$ we identify commer- cial spyware marketed exclusively to governments $NUM$ including Gamma 's FinSpy and Hacking Team 's Remote Control Sys- tem $NUM$ RCS $NUM$ 
We describe their use in Bahrain and the UAE $NUM$ and map out the potential broader scope of this activity by conduct- ing global scans of the corresponding command-and-control $NUM$ $HEX$ $NUM$ $HEX$ $NUM$ servers 
Finally $NUM$ we frame the real-world consequences of these campaigns via strong circumstantial evidence linking hacking to arrests $NUM$ interrogations $NUM$ and imprisonment 
Computer security research devotes extensive efforts to pro- tecting individuals against indiscriminate $NUM$ large-scale attacks such as those used by cybercriminals 
Recently $NUM$ the prob- lem of protecting institutions against targeted attacks conducted by nation-states $NUM$ so-called $NUM$ Advanced Persistent Threats $NUM$ $NUM$ has likewise elicited significant research interest 
Where these $NUM$ problem domains intersect $NUM$ however-targeted cyber attacks by nation-states against individuals-has received virtually no sig- nificant $NUM$ methodical research attention to date 
This new prob- lem space poses challenges that are both technically complex and of significant real-world importance 
In this work we undertake to characterize the emergent prob- lem space of nation-state Internet attacks against individuals engaged in pro-democracy or opposition movements 
While we lack the data to do so in $HEX$ fully comprehensive fashion $NUM$ we provide extensive detail from both technical and operational perspectives as seen in $NUM$ countries 
We view such character- izations as the fundamental first step necessary for the rigorous $NUM$ scientific pursuit of $HEX$ new problem space 
For our study we draw upon several years of research we have conducted into cases from Bahrain $NUM$ Syria and the United Arab Emirates 
We frame the nature of these attacks $NUM$ and the technology and infrastructure used to conduct them $NUM$ in the con- text of their impacts on real people 
We hope in the process to inspire additional research efforts addressing the difficult prob- lem of how to adequately protect individuals with very limited resources facing powerful adversaries 
As an illustration of this phenomenon $NUM$ consider the follow- ing anecdote $NUM$ pieced together from public reports and court documents 
At dawn on $NUM$ $NUM$ police raided the house of 17-year- old Ali Al-Shofa $NUM$ confiscated his laptop and phone $NUM$ and took him into custody 
He was charged with referring to Bahrain's King as $HEX$ $NUM$ dictator $NUM$ $NUM$ $NUM$ and $NUM$ fallen one $NUM$ $NUM$ $NUM$ on $HEX$ pseudonymous Twitter account $NUM$ $NUM$ alkawarahnews

Operators of $NUM$ alkawarahnews later forwarded $HEX$ suspicious private message to $NUM$ of the authors 
The message was received on $NUM$ on $HEX$ Facebook account linked to the Twitter handle $NUM$ and contained $HEX$ link to $HEX$ protest video $NUM$ purport- edly sent by an anti-government individual 
The link redirected through iplogger.org $NUM$ $HEX$ service that records the IP address of anyone who clicks 
Analytics for the link indicate that it had been clicked once from inside Bahrain 
On $NUM$ $NUM$ Ali was sentenced to $NUM$ year in prison 
Ali 's case is an example of the larger phenomenon we in- vestigate $NUM$ attacks against activists $NUM$ dissidents $NUM$ trade unionists $NUM$ human rights campaigners $NUM$ journalists $NUM$ and members of NGOs $NUM$ henceforth $NUM$ targets $NUM$ $NUM$ in the Middle East 
The lat- ter advertises that governments need its technology to $NUM$ look through their target 's eyes $NUM$ rather than rely solely on $NUM$ passive monitoring $NUM$ 
Overall $NUM$ the attacks we document are rarely technically novel 
In fact $NUM$ we suspect that the majority of at- tacks could $HEX$ substantially limited via well-known security practices $NUM$ settings $NUM$ and software updates 
We obtained the majority of our artifacts by encouraging in- dividuals who might $HEX$ targeted by governments to provide us with suspicious files and unsolicited links $NUM$ especially from un- familiar senders 
While this process has provided $HEX$ rich set of artifacts to analyze $NUM$ it does not permit us to claim our dataset is representative 
Our analysis links these attacks with $HEX$ common class of $HEX$ tor $NUM$ an attacker whose behavior $NUM$ choice of target $NUM$ or use of in- formation obtained in the attack $NUM$ aligns with the interests of $HEX$ government 
In some cases $NUM$ such as Ali 's $NUM$ the attackers appear to $HEX$ governments themselves $NUM$ in other cases $NUM$ they appear in- stead to $HEX$ pro-government actors $NUM$ ranging from patriotic $NUM$ not necessarily skilled volunteers to cyber mercenaries 
The phe- nomenon has been identified before $NUM$ such as in Libya $NUM$ when the fall of Gaddafi 's regime revealed direct government ties to hacking during the $NUM$ Civil War 
We make the following contributions $NUM$ $NUM$ We analyze the technology associated with targeted at- tacks $NUM$ e.g. $NUM$ malicious links $NUM$ spyware $NUM$ $NUM$ and trace it back to its programmers and manufacturers 
While the attacks are not novel-and indeed often involve technology used by the cybercrime underground-they are significant $HEX$ cause they have $HEX$ real-world impact and visibility $NUM$ and are connected to governments 
In addition $NUM$ we often find amateurish mistakes in either the attacker 's technology or operations $NUM$ indicating that energy spent countering these threats can realize significant benefits 
We do not $NUM$ how- ever $NUM$ conclude that all nation-state attacks or attackers are incompetent $NUM$ and we suspect that some attacks have evaded our detection 
$NUM$ When possible $NUM$ we empirically characterize the attacks and technology we have observed

In the past decades $NUM$ $HEX$ rich body of academic work has grown to document and understand government Internet censorship $NUM$ in- cluding nationwide censorship campaigns like the Great Fire- wall of China $NUM$ $NUM$ $NUM$ $NUM$ 
Research on governmental Internet surveillance and activities like law-enforcement interception is $HEX$ comparatively smaller area 
Some academic work looks at government use of devices to enable censorship $NUM$ such as key- word blacklists for Chinese chat clients $NUM$ or the Green Dam censorware that was to $HEX$ deployed on all new computers sold in China 
We are aware of only limited previous work looking at advanced threat actors targeting activists with hack- ing $NUM$ though this work has not always been able to establish ev- idence of government connections 
Platforms used by potential targets $NUM$ such as GMail $NUM$ Twitter $NUM$ and Facebook increasingly make transport- layer encryption the default $NUM$ obscuring communications from most network surveillance 
This use of encryption $NUM$ along with the global nature of many social movements $NUM$ and the role of diaspora groups $NUM$ likely makes hacking increasingly attractive $NUM$ especially to states who are unable to request or compel content from these platforms 
Indeed $NUM$ the increasing use of encryption and the global nature of targets have both been cited by pur- veyors of $NUM$ lawful intercept $NUM$ trojans in their marketing materi- als $NUM$ $NUM$ $NUM$ 
In $NUM$ notable case in $NUM$ $NUM$ UAE telecom firm Eti- salat distributed $HEX$ system update to its then $NUM$ BlackBerry subscribers that contained spyware to read encrypted Black- Berry e-mail from the device 
The spyware was discovered when the update drastically slowed users $NUM$ phones 
In con- trast to country-scale distribution $NUM$ our work looks at this kind of pro-government and government-linked surveillance through highly targeted attacks 
The term APT $NUM$ Advanced Persistent Threat $NUM$ refers to $HEX$ sophisticated cyber-attacker who persistently attempts to tar- get an individual or group 
Work outside the academic community tracking government cyberattacks typically falls under this umbrella 
There has been significant work on APT outside the academic community $NUM$ especially among se- curity professionals $NUM$ threat intelligence companies $NUM$ and human rights groups 
Much of this work has focused on suspected government-on-government or government-on-corporation cy- ber attacks $NUM$ $NUM$ $NUM$ 
Meanwhile $NUM$ $HEX$ small but growing body of this research deals with attacks carried out by governments against opposition and activist groups operating within $NUM$ as well as outside their borders 
$NUM$ of the most notable cases is GhostNet $NUM$ $HEX$ large-scale cyber espionage campaign against the Tibetan independence movement $NUM$ $NUM$ $NUM$

This string suggests FinSpy $NUM$ $HEX$ product of Gamma Inter- national 
We $HEX$ vised $HEX$ fingerprint for the obfuscater and located $HEX$ structurally similar executable by searching $HEX$ large malware database 
Since it did not in- clude anti-VM code $NUM$ we ran it in TEMU $NUM$ an $HEX$ emulator $HEX$ signed for malware analysis 
TEMU captures instruction- level execution traces and provides support for taint-tracking 
The private key presumably resides on the $HEX$ $NUM$ $HEX$ server 
The weak AES keys make decryption of the data straightfor- ward 
We wrote $HEX$ program that generally can find these keys in under an hour $NUM$ exploiting the fact that many of the system clock readings occur within the same clock-update quantum 
In addition $NUM$ FinSpy 's AES code fails to encrypt the last block of data if less than the AES block size of $NUM$ bits $NUM$ leaving trail- ing plaintext 
While we suspect FinSpy 's cryptographic deficiencies reflect bugs $NUM$ it is also con- ceivable that the cryptography was deliberately weakened to facilitate $NUM$ government monitoring the surveillance of oth- ers 
Analyzing network traffic between our infected VM and the $HEX$ $NUM$ $HEX$ server revealed that the server used $HEX$ global IPID $NUM$ which allowed us to infer server activity by its progression

Targeted surveillance of individuals conducted by nation-states poses an exceptionally challenging security problem $NUM$ given the great imbalance of resources and expertise between the victims and the attackers 
We have sketched the nature of this problem space as reported to us by targeted individuals in $NUM$ Middle Eastern countries 
In- stead $NUM$ they employ prepackaged tools developed by vendors or acquired from the cybercrime underground

$NUM$ We aim with this work to inspire additional research efforts addressing the difficult problem of how to adequately protect individuals with very limited resources facing very powerful adversaries 
Open questions include robust $NUM$ practical detection of targeted attacks designed to exfiltrate data from $HEX$ victim's computer $NUM$ as well as detection of and defense against novel at- tack vectors $NUM$ like tampering with Internet connections to insert malware 
The task is highly challenging $NUM$ but the potential stakes are likewise very high

$NUM$ years ago $NUM$ we published our research into RedOctober $NUM$ $HEX$ complex cyber-espionage operation targeting diplomatic embassies worldwide 
We named it RedOctober because we started this investigation in October $NUM$ $NUM$ an unusually hot month 
After our announcement in January $NUM$ $NUM$ the RedOctober operation was promptly shut down and the network of $HEX$ $NUM$ Cs was dismantled 
As usually happens with these big operations $NUM$ considering the huge investment and number of resources behind it $NUM$ they do n't just $NUM$ go away $NUM$ forever 
Normally $NUM$ the group goes underground for $HEX$ few months $NUM$ redesigns the tools and the malware and resume operations 
See $NUM$ Since January $NUM$ $NUM$ we 've been on the lookout for $HEX$ possible RedOctober comeback 
$NUM$ possible hit was triggered when we observed Mevade $NUM$ an unusual piece of malware that appeared late in $NUM$ 
The Mevade $HEX$ $NUM$ $HEX$ name styles as well as some other technical similarities indicated $HEX$ connection to RedOctober $NUM$ but the link was weak 
It was n't until August $NUM$ that we observed something which made us wonder if RedOctober is back for good 
In August $NUM$ $NUM$ some of our users observed targeted attacks with $HEX$ variation of CVE-2012-0158 and an unusual set of malware 
We did $HEX$ quick analysis of the malware and it immediately stood out because of certain unusual things that are not very common in the APT world 
As we started digging into the operation $NUM$ more details emerged which supported this theory 
Perhaps the most unusual fact was that the Microsoft Office exploit did n't directly write $HEX$ Windows PE backdoor on disk 
The loader appears to $HEX$ different every time and internal strings indicate it is $NUM$ polymorphically $NUM$ generated 
According to their website $NUM$ CloudMe is owned and operated by CloudMe $HEX$ $NUM$ $HEX$ company based in Linköping $NUM$ Sweden 
$NUM$ Important note $NUM$ we do not believe that CloudMe is in any way related to the Cloud Atlas group $NUM$ the attackers simply create free accounts on this provider and abuse them for command-and-control $NUM$ 
Of course $NUM$ it should $HEX$ possible to reconfigure the malware to use any Cloud-based storage service that supports WebDAV 
Just like with RedOctober $NUM$ the top target of Cloud Atlas is Russia $NUM$ followed closely by Kazakhstan $NUM$ according to data from the Kaspersky Security Network $NUM$ KSN $NUM$ 
Actually $NUM$ we see an obvious overlap of targets between the $NUM$ $NUM$ with subtle differences which closely account for the geopolitical changes in the region that happened during the last $NUM$ years 
Both Cloud Atlas and RedOctober malware implants rely on $HEX$ similar construct $NUM$ with $HEX$ loader and the final payload that is stored encrypted and compressed in an external file 
There are some important differences though $NUM$ especially in the encryption algorithms used $NUM$ RC4 in RedOctober vs AES in Cloud Atlas 
The usage of the compression algorithms in Cloud Altas and RedOctober is another interesting similarity 
Both malicious programs share the code for LZMA compression algorithm 
In CloudAtlas it is used to compress the logs and to decompress the decrypted payload from the $HEX$ $NUM$ $HEX$ servers $NUM$ while in Red October the $NUM$ scheduler $NUM$ plugin uses it to decompress executable payloads from the $HEX$ $NUM$ $HEX$ 
It turns out that the implementation of the algorithm is identical in both malicious modules $NUM$ however the way it is invoked is $HEX$ bit different $NUM$ with additional input sanity checks $HEX$ to the CloudAtlas version 
Another interesting similarity between the malware families is the configuration of the build system used to compile the binaries 
Every binary created using the Microsoft Visual Studio toolchain has $HEX$ special header that contains information about the number of input object files and version information of the compilers used to create them $NUM$ the $NUM$ Rich $NUM$ header called so by the magic string that is used to identify it in the file 
We have been able to identify several RedOctober binaries that have $NUM$ Rich $NUM$ headers describing exactly the same layout of VC $NUM$ $NUM$ VC $NUM$ object files 
Although this does n't necessarily mean that the binaries were created on the same development computer $NUM$ they were definitely compiled using the same version of the Microsoft Visual Studio up to the build number version and using similar project configuration 
To summarize the similarities between the $NUM$ $NUM$ Finally $NUM$ perhaps the strongest connection comes from targeting 
In at least $NUM$ case $NUM$ the victim 's computer was attacked only twice in the last $NUM$ years $NUM$ with only $NUM$ malicious programs $NUM$ RedOctober and Cloud Atlas 
These and other details make us believe that CloudAtlas represents $HEX$ rebirth of the RedOctober attacks 
Following big announcements and public exposures of targeted attack operations $NUM$ APT groups behave in $HEX$ predictable manner 
Other groups that are more nervous about exposure go in $HEX$ hibernation mode for months or years 
Some may never return using the same tools and techniques 
However $NUM$ when $HEX$ major cyber-espionage operation is exposed $NUM$ the attackers are unlikely to completely shut down everything 
They simply go offline for some time $NUM$ completely reshuffle their tools and return with rejuvenated forces 
We believe this is also the case of RedOctober $NUM$ which makes $HEX$ classy return with Cloud Atlas

We use the term $NUM$ threat group $NUM$ to refer to actors who work together to target and penetrate networks of interest 
These individuals may share the same set of tasks $NUM$ coordinate targets $NUM$ and share tools and methodology 
The art of attributing disparate intrusion activities to the same threat group is not always simple 
Different groups may use similar intrusion methodologies and common tools $NUM$ particularly those that are widely available on the Internet $NUM$ such as pwdump $NUM$ HTran $NUM$ or Gh0st RAT 
There may $HEX$ overlaps between groups caused by the sharing of malware or exploits they have authored $NUM$ or even the sharing of personnel 
Individual threat actors may move between groups either temporarily or permanently 
$HEX$ threat actor may also $HEX$ $HEX$ private citizen who is hired by multiple groups 
Multiple groups $NUM$ on occasion $NUM$ compromise the same target within the same timeframe 
Distinguishing $NUM$ threat group from another is possible with enough information $NUM$ analytical experience $NUM$ and tools to piece it all together 
We can analyze multiple incidents and tell by the evidence left behind that $HEX$ given incident was the result of $NUM$ threat group and not another 
Threat actors leave behind various forensic details 
Their emails may contain certain patterns $NUM$ files have specific names $NUM$ MD5 hashes $NUM$ timestamps $NUM$ custom functions $NUM$ and encryption algorithms 
Their backdoors may have command and control IP addresses or domain names embedded 
These are just $HEX$ few examples of the myriad of forensic details that we consider when distinguishing $NUM$ threat group from another 
At the most basic level $NUM$ we say that $NUM$ intrusion events are attributed to the same group when we have collected enough indicators to show beyond $HEX$ reasonable doubt that the same actor or group of actors were involved 
We track all of the indicators and significant linkages associated with identified threat groups in $HEX$ proprietary database that comprises millions of nodes and linkages between them 
In this way $NUM$ we can always go back and answer $NUM$ why $NUM$ we associated cyber threat activity with $HEX$ particular group

We suspect threat actors are leveraging their access to compromised websites belonging to NGOs and non-profits to target other organizations in the same industries 
These websites are often visited by organization employees and other organizations in the same industries $NUM$ allowing threat actors to move laterally within already compromised networks or gain access to new networks 
While FireEye has not attributed this activity to $HEX$ specific threat group $NUM$ we frequently observe China-based threat actors target non-profits and NGOs $NUM$ and we suspect that they seek to monitor activity within their borders that may lead to domestic unrest or embarrass the Chinese government 
For example $NUM$ in $NUM$ $NUM$ FireEye observed China-based threat actors steal grant applications and activity reports specifically related to an international NGO 's China-based activities 
We suspects threat actors sought to monitor these programs and involved individuals 
The $NUM$ organizations whose websites are hosting the malicious iframes have China-based operations 
FireEye is releasing information on this campaign to allow organizations to investigate and prepare for this activity in their networks 
We believe non-profits and NGOs remain at elevated risk of intrusion and should $HEX$ especially wary of attempts to compromise their networks using SWC 
Threat actors may use SWCs to achieve this goal $NUM$ but FireEye does not discount the possibility that threat actors will use other means at their disposal $NUM$ including phishing 
Based on past threat actor activity in this industry $NUM$ FireEye expects threat actors are motivated to steal programmatic data and monitor organizations $NUM$ programs in specific countries 
If China-based threat actors are behind the observed campaign $NUM$ FireEye expects that organizations with operations in China are high-priority targets 
FireEye currently has detection measures in place that should allow users of FireEye products to detect this SWC activity 
It is also likely that other industries or organizations were affected by this SWC activity $NUM$ since these sites are public facing and frequently visited 
Special thanks to Google 's Billy Leonard for providing additional information and research 
Thanks to the following authors for their contributions $NUM$ Mike Oppenheim $NUM$ Ned Moran $NUM$ and Steve Stone

Cyber espionage has been $HEX$ hot topic through the last years 
Computer attacks known as $NUM$ APT $NUM$ $NUM$ Advanced Persistent Threat $NUM$ have become widely reported and emphasized by the media $NUM$ damages are now considered as real and strategic trends are moving in cyber defense 
AIRBUS Defence $NUM$ Space $NUM$ CyberSecurity unit responds to such attacks for its customers every day $NUM$ developing $HEX$ complete range of solutions 
Today $NUM$ we decided to release publicly information on $HEX$ specific group of APT attackers known as $NUM$ Pitty Tiger $NUM$ 
This information comes directly from investigations led by our Threat Intelligence 
Pitty Tiger is $HEX$ group of attackers that have been active since at least $NUM$ 
They have targeted private companies in several sectors $NUM$ such as defense and telecommunications $NUM$ but also at least $NUM$ government 
We have been able to track down this group of attackers and can provide detailed information about them 
We were able to collect and reveal their $NUM$ malware arsenal $NUM$ 
We also analyzed their technical organization 
Our investigations indicate that Pitty Tiger has not used any 0day vulnerability so far $NUM$ rather they prefer using custom malware $NUM$ developed for the group 's exclusive usage 
Our discoveries indicate that Pitty Tiger is $HEX$ group of attackers with the ability to stay under the radar $NUM$ yet still not as mature as other groups of attackers we monitor 
Pitty Tiger is probably not $HEX$ state-sponsored group of attackers 
They lack the experience and financial support that one would expect from state-sponsored attackers 
We suppose this group is opportunistic and sells its services to probable competitors of their targets in the private sector 
We have been able to leverage several attackers profiles $NUM$ showing that the Pitty Tiger group is fairly small compared to other APT groups $NUM$ which is probably why we saw them work on $HEX$ very limited amount of targets 
At the end of this report $NUM$ we provide indicators of compromise to help people detect current Pitty Tiger attacks 
APT attacks follow what we call the $NUM$ APT kill chain $NUM$ 
The kill chain describes briefly the way attackers do perform their actions 
It can $HEX$ summarized by the following scheme $NUM$ The reconnaissance phase commences when an attacker selects $HEX$ new target and involves the acquisition of information about that target 
There is very little information available about this phase $NUM$ and there is little data about it 
The only way to collect information about this phase would $HEX$ to already monitor all attackers $NUM$ actions at this step $NUM$ which is hardly feasible 
The longer the attackers spend time in attempting to understand their target and its online presence $NUM$ the easier it will $HEX$ to find efficient ways to penetrate that company 's systems 
This reconnaissance phase is both about finding information to break into the targeted network successfully and about searching for data which could help to accelerate sensitive information isolation $NUM$ like the name of $HEX$ key employee for example $NUM$ 
This phase mostly relies on open sources from the Internet $NUM$ social networks $NUM$ press releases $NUM$ white papers $NUM$ corporate websites $NUM$ search engines $NUM$ but also on some active tools like vulnerability scanners etc 
At this stage $NUM$ the APT attackers have $HEX$ solid knowledge of their target and its key employees 
In fact $NUM$ they can even send just $HEX$ single e-mail 
The method has $NUM$ major drawback $NUM$ it will also infect third parties who visit the website 
Attackers have developed ways to avoid this 
If their reconnaissance phase has been done effectively $NUM$ they already know all IP ranges used by the target company 
Direct attacks against servers of the target can also $HEX$ $HEX$ way to penetrate the target 's network 
In case $NUM$ backdoor falls $NUM$ there will $HEX$ others 
They use lateral moves between machines inside the network $NUM$ and look for everything they need 
This step is very hard to detect $NUM$ since they only use valid credentials and legitimate administration tools such as PsExec 
This phase is not the end of an APT attack 
For more information about all the APT phases $NUM$ please refer to our APT Kill Chain blog post serie

This group of attackers seems to know in advance when these individuals will arrive and depart from their high-end hotels 
So $NUM$ the attackers lay in wait until these travelers arrive and connect to the Internet

Those portals are now reviewed $NUM$ cleaned and undergoing $HEX$ further review and hardening process

The attack technique blurs the line between $HEX$ couple of common APT tactics $NUM$ fairly inaccurate $NUM$ watering holes $NUM$ or $NUM$ strategic web compromises $NUM$ and more accurate spearphishing techniques 
In this case $NUM$ the Darkhotel attackers wait for their victim to connect to the Internet over the hotel Wi-Fi or the cable in their room

The Darkhotel actors typically sign their backdoors with digital certificates of $NUM$ kind or another 
However $NUM$ the certificates originally chosen by this crew are very interesting because of their weak keys and likely abuse by attackers 
Here is $HEX$ listing of the certs that were commonly used to sign Darkhotel malcode $NUM$ requiring advanced mathematical capabilities to factorize the keys at the time 
They are not the only certificates used by the group 
More recent activity suggests that the group has stolen certificates to sign their code 
All related cases of signed Darkhotel malware share the same Root Certificate Authority and Intermediate Certificate Authority that issued certificates with weak md5 keys $NUM$ RSA $NUM$ bits $NUM$ 
We are confident that our Darkhotel threat actor fraudulently duplicated these certificates to sign its malware 
These keys were not stolen 
Many of the certificates were noted in $HEX$ $NUM$ Fox­IT post $NUM$ RSA­512 Certificates Abused in the Wild $NUM$ 
To further support this speculation please note the non­specific Microsoft Security Advisory below $NUM$ the Mozilla advisory addressing the issue at the time $NUM$ and the Entrust responses 
From Microsoft 's security advisory from Thursday $NUM$ November $NUM$ $NUM$ $NUM$ $NUM$ $NUM$ Microsoft is aware that DigiCert Sdn 
Bhd $NUM$ $HEX$ Malaysian subordinate certifica- tion authority $NUM$ $HEX$ $NUM$ under Entrust and GTE CyberTrust $NUM$ has issued $NUM$ certifi- cates with weak $NUM$ bit keys 
While this is not $HEX$ vulnerability in $HEX$ Microsoft product $NUM$ this issue affects all supported releases of Microsoft Windows 
There is no indication that any certificates were issued fraudulently 
Instead $NUM$ cryptographically weak keys have allowed some of the certificates to $HEX$ dupli- cated and used in $HEX$ fraudulent manner 
Microsoft is providing an update for all supported releases of Microsoft Windows that revokes the trust in DigiCert Sdn 
Bhd 
The update revokes the trust of the following $NUM$ intermediate $HEX$ certificates $NUM$ Digisign Server ID $NUM$ $NUM$ Enrich $NUM$ $NUM$ issued by Entrust.net Certification Authority $NUM$ $NUM$ $NUM$ Digisign Server ID $NUM$ Enrich $NUM$ $NUM$ issued by GTE CyberTrust Global Root $NUM$ From Mozilla 's $NUM$ response $NUM$ $NUM$ While there is no indication they were issued fraudulently $NUM$ the weak keys have allowed the certificates to $HEX$ compromised 
Furthermore $NUM$ certificates from this $HEX$ contain several technical issues 
They lack an EKU extension specifying their intended usage and they have been issued without revocation information 
$NUM$ From Entrust 's response $NUM$ $NUM$ There is no evidence that the Digicert Malaysia certificate authorities have been compromised 
$NUM$ Here are some notes on the costs and technical requirements of attacking these certificates 
The computing power required to crack and factor an RSA $NUM$ bit key was $NUM$ $NUM$ and the period of time required was about $NUM$ weeks 
$NUM$ see http $NUM$ //lukenotricks 
blogspot.co.at/2010/03/rsa­512­factoring­service­two­weeks.html $NUM$ In October $NUM$ $NUM$ Tom Ritter reported that it would cost about $NUM$ $NUM$ $NUM$ $NUM$ $NUM$ per- haps even as little as $NUM$ $NUM$ 
Going even further back $NUM$ there was much discussion about the technical meth- ods of cracking these keys $NUM$ DJ Bernstein 's $NUM$ paper on building $HEX$ machine reducing the cost of integer factorization with Number Field Sieve techniques $NUM$ breaking $NUM$ bit RSA keys 
RSA 's reaction and $NUM$ statement on whether or not $NUM$ bit RSA keys are broken $NUM$ $NUM$ NIST offered $HEX$ table of proposed key sizes for discussion at its key man- agement workshop in November $NUM$ $NUM$ $NUM$ $NUM$

In this section $NUM$ we explain in more detail the risks of remote attacks on the Android devices 
Android uses the JavaScript binding method addJavascriptInterface to enable JavaScript code running inside $HEX$ WebView to access the app 's Java methods $NUM$ also known as the Javascript bridge $NUM$ 
However $NUM$ it is widely known that this feature $NUM$ if not used carefully $NUM$ presents $HEX$ potential security risk when running on Android API $NUM$ $NUM$ Android $NUM$ $NUM$ or below 
We call this the JavaScript-Binding-Over-HTTP $NUM$ JBOH $NUM$ vulnerability 
This applies to insecure HTTPS channels as well 
Based on the official data in June $NUM$ $NUM$ $NUM$ $NUM$ of Android devices are still running API≤16 
Note that API $NUM$ $NUM$ platforms are not necessarily secure 
If the app is targeting at $HEX$ lower API level $NUM$ Android will still run it with the lower API level for compatibility reasons

We call these exposed JS binding annotation interfaces $NUM$ JS Sidedoors

It appears this method makes sending SMS easy

Android Open Source Project $NUM$ AOSP $NUM$ classifies Android permissions into several protec- tion levels $NUM$ $NUM$ normal $NUM$ $NUM$ $NUM$ dangerous $NUM$ $NUM$ $NUM$ system $NUM$ $NUM$ $NUM$ signature $NUM$ and $NUM$ development $NUM$ $NUM$ $NUM$ 
Dangerous permissions $NUM$ may $HEX$ displayed to the user and require confirmation before pro- ceeding $NUM$ or some other approach may $HEX$ taken to avoid the user automatically allowing the use of such facilities 
$NUM$ In contrast $NUM$ normal permissions are automatically granted at installation $NUM$ $NUM$ without asking for the user 's explicit approval $NUM$ though the user always has the option to review these permissions before installing $NUM$ $NUM$ 
If an app requests both dangerous permissions and normal permissions $NUM$ Android only displays the dangerous per- missions by default 
If an app requests only normal permissions $NUM$ Android does n't display any permission to the user 
We have found that certain $NUM$ normal $NUM$ permissions have dangerous security impacts 
These $NUM$ permissions enable an app to query $NUM$ insert $NUM$ delete $NUM$ or modify all launcher configuration settings $NUM$ including icon insertion or modification 
After our notification $NUM$ Google has patched this vulnerability in Android $NUM$ and has released the patch to its OEM partners

$HEX$ summary of the $HEX$ IP addresses $NUM$ Snort signatures $NUM$ Listening Implant $NUM$ Lightweight Backdoor $NUM$ Proxy Tool $NUM$ Malware associated with the cyber threat actor $NUM$ Below are potential YARA signatures to detect malware binaries on host machines $NUM$ Because of the highly destructive functionality of the malware $NUM$ an organization infected with the malware could experience operational impacts including loss of intellectual property $NUM$ IP $NUM$ and disruption of critical systems

Implement the indicators of compromise within your systems for detection and mitigation purposes 
Encourage users to transfer critical files to network shares $NUM$ to allow for central backed up 
Execute daily backups of all critical systems 
Periodically execute an $NUM$ offline $NUM$ backup of critical files to removable media 
Establish emergency communications plans should network resources become unavailable 
Isolate any critical networks $NUM$ including operations networks $NUM$ from business systems 
Identify critical systems and evaluate the need for having on-hand spares to quickly restore service 
Ensure antivirus is up to date 
Disable credential caching for all desktop devices with particular importance on critical systems such as servers and restrict the number of cached credential for all portable devices to no more than $NUM$ if possible 
This can $HEX$ accomplished through $HEX$ Group Policy Object $NUM$ GPO $NUM$ 
Disable AutoRun and Autoplay for any removable media device 
Prevent or limit the use of all removable media devices on systems to limit the spread or introduction of malicious software and possible exfiltration data $NUM$ except where there is $HEX$ valid business case for use 
This business case must $HEX$ approved by the organization Chief IT Security Officer $NUM$ with policy/guidance on how such media should $HEX$ used 
Consider restricting account privileges 
It is our recommendation that all daily operations should $HEX$ executed using standard user accounts unless administrative privileges are required for that specific function 
Configure all standard user accounts to prevent the execution and installation of any unknown or unauthorized software 
Both standard and administrative accounts should have access only to services required for nominal daily duties $NUM$ enforcing the concept of separation of duties 
Lastly $NUM$ disable Web and email capabilities on administrative accounts 
Compromise of admin accounts is $NUM$ vector that allows malicious activity to become truly persistent in $HEX$ network environment 
Ensure that password policy rules are enforced and Admin password values are changed periodically 
Consider prohibiting hosts within the production environment or DMZ from sharing an Active Directory enterprise with hosts on other networks 
Each environment should have separate forests within Active Directory $NUM$ with no trust relationships allowed between the forests if at all possible 
If necessary $NUM$ the trust relationships should $HEX$ one-way with the low integrity environment trusting the higher integrity environment 
Consider deployment of $HEX$ coaching page with click through acceptance $NUM$ these are traditionally deployed in an environment to log the acceptance of network acceptable use policy or to notify users of monitoring 
Coaching pages also provide some measure of protection from automated malicious activity 
This occurs because automated malware is normally incapable of physically clicking an acceptance radial button 
Automated malware is traditionally hardcoded to execute $NUM$ then retrieve commands or additional executables from the Internet 
If the malware is unable to initiate an active connection $NUM$ the full train of infection is potentially halted 
The danger still exists that the physical user will authorize access $NUM$ but through the use of coaching pages $NUM$ infections can $HEX$ limited or at least the rate of infection reduced 
Monitor logs $NUM$ Maintain and actively monitor $HEX$ centralized logging solution that keeps track of all anomalous and potentially malicious activity 
Ensure that all network operating systems $NUM$ web browsers $NUM$ and other related network hardware and software remain updated with all current patches and fixes 
Organizations should review Security Tip Handling Destructive Malware $NUM$ ST13-003 and evaluate their capabilities encompassing planning $NUM$ preparation $NUM$ detection $NUM$ and response for such an event 
Always keep your patch levels up to date $NUM$ especially on computers that host public services accessible through the firewall $NUM$ such as HTTP $NUM$ FTP $NUM$ mail $NUM$ and DNS services 
Build host systems $NUM$ especially critical systems such as servers $NUM$ with only essential applications and components required to perform the intended function 
Any unused applications or functions should $HEX$ removed or disabled $NUM$ if possible $NUM$ to limit the attack surface of the host 
Implement network segmentation through V-LANs to limit the spread of malware 
Consider the deployment of Software Restriction Policy set to only allow the execution of approved software $NUM$ application whitelisting $NUM$ 
Recommend the whitelisting of legitimate executable directories to prevent the execution of potentially malicious binaries 
Consider the use of two-factor authentication methods for accessing privileged root level accounts or systems 
Consider deploying $HEX$ two-factor authentication through $HEX$ hardened IPsec/VPN gateway with split-tunneling prohibited for secure remote access 
Deny direct Internet access $NUM$ except through the use of proxies for Enterprise servers and workstations 
Perform regular content filtering at the proxies or external firewall points of presence 
Also consider the deployment of an explicit versus transparent proxy policy 
Implement $HEX$ Secure Socket Layer $NUM$ SSL $NUM$ inspection capability to inspect both ingress and egress encrypted network traffic for potential malicious activity 
Isolate network services $NUM$ such as email and Web application servers by utilizing $HEX$ secure multi-tenant virtualization technology 
This will limit the damage sustained from $HEX$ compromise or attack of $HEX$ single network component 
Implement best practice guidance and policy to restrict the use of non-Foundation assets for processing or accessing Foundation-controlled data or systems $NUM$ e.g. $NUM$ working from home $NUM$ or using $HEX$ personal device while at the office $NUM$ 
It is difficult to enforce corporate policies $NUM$ detect intrusions $NUM$ and conduct forensic analysis or remediate compromises on non-corporate owned devices

Control system devices should not directly $HEX$ the Internet 
Place control system networks behind firewalls $NUM$ and isolate or air gap them from the business network 
When remote access is required $NUM$ use secure methods $NUM$ such as Virtual Private Networks $NUM$ VPNs $NUM$ $NUM$ recognizing that VPN is only as secure as the connected devices

$NUM$ $NUM$ months later $NUM$ after the buzz around Uroburos $NUM$ aka Snake or Turla $NUM$ we now identified $HEX$ new generation of Agent.BTZ

ComRAT $NUM$ in its version $NUM$ $NUM$ shows the same behavior

The analyzed file is the latest version we identified $NUM$ v3.26

The major difference between this version and the older version $NUM$ s $NUM$ will $HEX$ described there

This library is the real payload

Concerning the version $NUM$ $NUM$ the malware uses $HEX$ new non-ASCII key

Another connection between the cases

In version $NUM$ $NUM$ the author changed the key and remove the known file name

Context Information Security distribute Context Threat Intelligence $NUM$ CTI $NUM$ reporting under the Traffic Light Protocol $NUM$ TLP $NUM$ $NUM$ $HEX$ method of classifying $HEX$ document in order to promote the distribution of sensitive information between individuals $NUM$ organisations or communities in $HEX$ controlled and trusted way $NUM$ based on the originator 's wishes 
The various levels of the TLP are represented by the following colours $NUM$ Sources may use TLP $NUM$ RED when information can not $HEX$ effectively acted upon by additional parties $NUM$ and could lead to impacts on $HEX$ party 's privacy $NUM$ reputation $NUM$ or operations if misused 
Recipients may not share TLP $NUM$ RED information with any parties outside of the specific exchange $NUM$ meeting $NUM$ or conversation in which it is originally disclosed 
TLP $NUM$ RED information will $HEX$ passed verbally or in person 
Sources may use TLP $NUM$ AMBER when information requires support to $HEX$ effectively acted upon $NUM$ but carries risks to privacy $NUM$ reputation $NUM$ or operations if shared outside of the organisations involved 
Recipients may only share TLP $NUM$ AMBER information with members of their own organisation who need to know $NUM$ and only as widely as necessary to act on that information 
Sources may use TLP $NUM$ GREEN when information is useful for the awareness of all participating organisations as well as with peers within the broader community or sector 
Recipients may share TLP $NUM$ GREEN information with peers and partner organisations within their sector or community $NUM$ but not via publicly accessible channels such as publication or posting publicly on the Internet 
Sources may use TLP $NUM$ WHITE when information carries minimal or no foreseeable risk of misuse $NUM$ in accordance with applicable rules and procedures for public release 
Subject to standard copyright rules $NUM$ TLP $NUM$ WHITE information may $HEX$ distributed freely $NUM$ without restriction

Citizen Lab researchers have developed the Targeted Threat Index $NUM$ TTI $NUM$ as $HEX$ tool to standardize information about the sophistication of targeted threats against civil society groups in our research 
The index captures information about the level of social engineering used $NUM$ $NUM$ Targeting Sophistication $NUM$ $NUM$ $NUM$ and adds $HEX$ Technical Sophistication value for the attack as $HEX$ multiplier 
Taken together it rates $HEX$ $NUM$ for Targeting Sophistication and $HEX$ $NUM$ for Technical Sophistication by our metric $NUM$ yielding $HEX$ TTI score of $NUM$ 
Citizen Lab research using the TTI has found that $NUM$ despite low levels of technical sophistication $NUM$ with well-crafted social engineering malware attacks remain highly effective against civil society groups

There are at least $NUM$ possible sources for this malware attack $NUM$ We evaluate each of these possibilities in turn $NUM$ drawing on the information available to us after almost $NUM$ years of tracking regime-linked malware

Regime-linked malware has $HEX$ number of common features that typically serve as distinguishing characteristics $NUM$ Social engineering focusing on the needs and interests of the opposition 
Frequent use of Dynamic DNS providers like no-ip 
These characteristics are not all present in every sample $NUM$ but we have typically found $NUM$ or more in almost every binary we have examined that is Syrian regime-linked 
This malware attack differs from known regime-linked groups in each of these elements 
Nor does it have RAT functionality 
The lack of overlap in Tactics $NUM$ Techniques $NUM$ and Procedures $NUM$ TTPs $NUM$ between this attack and prior attacks does not rule out Syrian regime-linked attackers 
It is possible that regime-linked groups are trying $HEX$ new approach 
However $NUM$ given that known regime-linked groups continued to remain active during the same date range using familiar TTPs $NUM$ this scenario seems unlikely 
In addition $NUM$ it would $HEX$ strange for regime-linked malware groups to undertake significant effort to prepare and send an implant that has significantly less functionality than what they commonly use 
Taken together $NUM$ we find this evidence supports the hypothesis that familiar regime-linked groups did not conduct the attack 
RSS operates in territory controlled by ISIS $NUM$ and has $HEX$ extensive targeting by ISIS 
Currently $NUM$ they appear to $HEX$ directly targeted by ISIS for kidnappings and other retaliation $NUM$ including executions 
In addition $NUM$ ISIS supporters have explicitly suggested that the group is under surveillance and actively hunted

We think there are several features of the malware attack that align with the needs and constraints of ISIS and its supporters in Ar-Raqqah $NUM$ more so than other groups $NUM$ as we understand them 
The social media activity of members of RSS is often highly public

We speculate that if an attacker were interested in maintaining long-term surveillance of the activities of RSS they could have employed $HEX$ RAT 
However $NUM$ if the attacker were interested in unmasking the location of its targets so they could $HEX$ physically tracked down $NUM$ collecting IP data and system info would $HEX$ $HEX$ more reasonable approach 
ISIS or its supporters clearly have $HEX$ strong interest in the $NUM$ rudimentary $NUM$ location tracking of the members of RSS that this malware provides 
Internet connectivity in Raqqah is extremely limited $NUM$ and some of it is under ISIS control 
Knowing the IP address of $HEX$ target could quickly narrow down targets to specific locations $NUM$ and specific Internet services $NUM$ or Internet cafes in Raqqah 
Given that the identities and locations of RSS members are closely guarded $NUM$ such information would hold significant intelligence value for ISIS 
Armed with this kind of information $NUM$ ISIS could physically harm people within Raqqah $NUM$ and it is also possible that they have the ability to operate in some capacity in border areas of Turkey $NUM$ 
Little is publicly known about the technical capabilities of ISIS and its supporters $NUM$ however $NUM$ reports have begun to emerge suggesting that ISIS is interested in expanding its abilities 
In addition $NUM$ ISIS has reportedly gained the support of at least $NUM$ individual with some experience with social engineering and hacking $NUM$ Junaid Hussain $NUM$ aka TriCk $NUM$ $NUM$ $HEX$ former member of teamp0ison hacking team 
While Mr. Hussain and associates have reportedly made threats against Western governments $NUM$ it is possible that he or others working with ISIS have quietly supported an effort to identify the targeted organization $NUM$ which is $HEX$ highly visible thorn in the side of ISIS 
It is possible that the attack is the product of actors working for unknown purposes and targeting RSS 
Given the activities of RSS $NUM$ however $NUM$ it is unclear who this might $HEX$ 
It is not possible $NUM$ for example $NUM$ to reject the theory that some unknown group within the FSA $NUM$ or other groups opposing the Assad regime are responsible 
Citizen journalists in Ar-Raqqah were previously critical of arbitrary arrests carried out by non-ISIS groups in $NUM$ 
However $NUM$ it is unclear why those groups $NUM$ which no longer control Ar-Raqqah $NUM$ would $HEX$ interested in RSS in November $NUM$ 
It is likely that third party actors $NUM$ including several intelligence services $NUM$ are closely monitoring various actors in the conflict through $HEX$ range of electronic means 
However $NUM$ there is little reason to suggest that they would use $HEX$ tailored but technically rudimentary attack to target RSS in particular 
After considering each possibility $NUM$ we find strong but inconclusive circumstantial evidence to support $HEX$ link to ISIS 
However $NUM$ we are unable to connect this attack directly to ISIS $NUM$ Mr. Hussain $NUM$ or other ISIS supporters 
If indeed ISIS or its supporters are responsible $NUM$ it seems reasonable that such an offensive capability may still $HEX$ in development 
We hope that publishing this report will draw attention to $HEX$ new and concerning threat that includes ISIS critics among its targets 
If ISIS is responsible $NUM$ while this attack targets in-country impediments to ISIS objectives $NUM$ other targets may include ideological or military adversaries abroad 
Whether or not ISIS is responsible $NUM$ this attack is likely the work of $HEX$ non-regime threat actor who may $HEX$ just beginning to field $HEX$ still-rudimentary capability in the Syrian conflict 
The entry costs for engaging in malware attacks in $HEX$ conflict like the Syrian Civil War are low $NUM$ and made lower by the fact that the rule of law is nonexistent for large parts of the country 
In still other parts $NUM$ under regime control $NUM$ $NUM$ malware attacks appear to $HEX$ state sanctioned 
Citizen Lab research into targeted digital threats against civil society confirms that civil society groups $HEX$ grave threats from targeted malware attacks $NUM$ despite being under-resourced to defend against them 
The case highlighted here is no exception $NUM$ lack of IT and security resources have made it difficult for the Syrian opposition to address targeted and persistent digital threats against them 
In addition $NUM$ if ISIS is indeed responsible $NUM$ this case suggests how easy it is for belligerents in $HEX$ conflict to begin fielding basic offensive digital capabilities $NUM$ and how quickly the capabilities can $HEX$ pointed at unarmed civil society groups 
As most organizations working on issues surrounding Syria are aware $NUM$ malware delivered with good social engineering is $HEX$ constant source of danger 
This particular attack can $HEX$ prevented by not opening files sent by unknown persons 
However $NUM$ many attacks in Syria come from hijacked accounts and impersonate people known to the targets 
Social engineering remains an unsolved problem $NUM$ and continues to compromise groups throughout the Syrian opposition and their supporters 
This attack reaffirms the dangers posed by social engineering attacks $NUM$ whether they deliver phishing campaigns or malware

In the world of malware threats $NUM$ only $HEX$ few rare examples can truly $HEX$ considered groundbreaking and almost peerless 
What we have seen in Regin is just such $HEX$ class of malware 
Its stealth combines many of the most advanced techniques that we have ever seen in use 
The level of sophistication and complexity of Regin suggests that the development of this threat could have taken well-resourced teams of developers many months or years to develop and maintain 
Regin is $HEX$ multi-staged $NUM$ modular threat $NUM$ meaning that it has $HEX$ number of components $NUM$ each depending on others $NUM$ to perform attack operations 
This modular approach gives flexibility to the threat operators as they can load custom features tailored to individual targets when required 
Some custom payloads are very advanced and exhibit $HEX$ high degree of expertise in specialist sectors 
This modular approach has been seen in other sophisticated malware families such as Flamer and Weevil $NUM$ The Mask $NUM$ $NUM$ while the multi-stage loading architecture is similar to that seen in the Duqu/Stuxnet family of threats 
Regin is different to what are commonly referred to as $NUM$ traditional $NUM$ advanced persistent threats $NUM$ APTs $NUM$ $NUM$ both in its techniques and ultimate purpose 
Regin 's purpose is different 
This report provides $HEX$ technical analysis of Regin based on $HEX$ number of identified samples and components 
This analysis illustrates Regin 's architecture and the many payloads at its disposal 
Regin is $HEX$ multi-purpose data collection tool which dates back several years 
Symantec first began looking into this threat in the fall of $NUM$ 
Multiple versions of Regin were found in the wild $NUM$ targeting several corporations $NUM$ institutions $NUM$ academics $NUM$ and individuals 
It also has the ability to load custom features tailored to individual targets 
Some of Regin 's custom payloads point to $HEX$ high level of specialist knowledge in particular sectors $NUM$ such as telecoms infrastructure software $NUM$ on the part of the developers 
More advanced payload modules designed with specific goals in mind were also found in our investigations 
In some cases $NUM$ Symantec was only able to retrieve the threat samples but not the files containing stolen data

Version $NUM$ appears to have been used from at least $NUM$ to $NUM$ 
Version $NUM$ has been used from $NUM$ onwards $NUM$ though it may have possibly been used earlier

Version $NUM$ samples found after this date seem to have been improperly removed or were no longer accessible to the attackers for removal 
This report is based primarily on our analysis of Regin version $NUM$

Regin has $HEX$ six-stage architecture 
The later stages bring Regin 's main payloads into play 
This section presents $HEX$ brief overview of the format and purpose of each stage 
The most interesting stages are the executables and data files stored in Stages $NUM$ and $NUM$ 
The initial Stage $NUM$ driver is the only plainly visible code on the computer 
Symantec Security Response has not obtained the Regin dropper at the time of writing 
The dropper could $HEX$ transient rather than acting as an executable file and may possibly $HEX$ part of the infection vector exploit code 
Once this happens $NUM$ there are no remaining plainly visible code artifacts 
The first $NUM$ bytes are used and the remaining bytes are set to zero 
The second byte indicates the exclusive maximum number of instances allowed to run $NUM$ which is set to $NUM$ 
This means no more than $NUM$ instance should run at any time 
The first byte indicates how many instances were run or attempted to run 
Therefore $NUM$ the potential combinations for the first $NUM$ bytes are $NUM$ Stage $NUM$ is $HEX$ kernel mode DLL and is not stored in the traditional file system 
Stage $NUM$ can $HEX$ found in the following locations $NUM$ The file is $NUM$ to $NUM$ times the size of the driver in Stage $NUM$ 
Stages $NUM$ and above are based on $HEX$ modular framework of code modules 
These modules offer functions through $HEX$ private $NUM$ custom interface 
Each file in stages $NUM$ and above can $NUM$ export $NUM$ functionality to other parts of Regin 
In the case of Stage $NUM$ $NUM$ the following primitives are offered $NUM$ These primitives are provided through $HEX$ custom export methodology 
The Stage $NUM$ DLL exports $HEX$ wide range of functionality through $HEX$ custom export methodology 
The interface used to export functionality does not make use of the traditional Windows DLL export mechanism by name or ordinal 
Exported Regin methods are referenced by $HEX$ tuple consisting of $HEX$ major and minor number 
Stage $NUM$ exports hundreds of methods $NUM$ organized into $NUM$ different major groups 
The numbers used vary across versions

$NUM$ $NUM$ System $NUM$ $doubleSlash$ $NUM$ Contains $HEX$ user mode version of Stage $NUM$ 
The files are injected into services.exe

Stage $NUM$ consists of the main Regin payload functionality 
Stage $NUM$ files are EVFS containers containing other files $NUM$ Regin 's payload involves the DLLs contained in the SystemLog.evt EVFS container 
The payload functionality differs depending on the targeted computer 
Custom payload files will likely $HEX$ delivered for each specific environment 
Such files are accessed by the major routines 3Dh 
Known extensions for EVFS containers are *.evt and *.imd 
The structure of $HEX$ container is similar to the FAT file system 
$NUM$ major difference is that files do not have $HEX$ name $NUM$ instead $NUM$ they 're identified using $HEX$ binary tag 
The tag itself is the concatenation of $HEX$ major number and $HEX$ minor number 
The major number typically indicates the major function group that will handle the file 
$HEX$ container starts with the header in Table $NUM$ $NUM$ little-endian ordering $NUM$ 
The header is followed by the file entry table $NUM$ Table $NUM$ $NUM$ 
Each file entry is $NUM$ bytes long 
The sectors follow $NUM$ Table $NUM$ $NUM$ 
$HEX$ sector of sectsize bytes starts with $HEX$ DWORD pointing to the next sector $NUM$ if the file does not fit within single sector $NUM$ $NUM$ followed by sectsize-4 bytes of payload data 
Other layers of encryption and compression may also $HEX$ in place $NUM$ although those would $HEX$ handled by higher level components 
The string 'shit $NUM$ is scattered in the packet for data validation 
In addition $NUM$ CRC checks use the seed $NUM$ $NUM$

Blue Coat researchers have uncovered $HEX$ previously-undocumented $NUM$ highly automated $NUM$ and extremely sophisticated framework for performing targeted attacks 
Initial malware components were embedded in Rich Text Format $NUM$ RTF $NUM$ files 
Malware payloads designed for $HEX$ wide array of potential devices $NUM$ including home routers and mobile devices running iOS $NUM$ BlackBerryOS or Android $NUM$ were also recovered during the course of our research 
The malware components of this framework follow $HEX$ plugin model $NUM$ where new malware rely on other $NUM$ previously delivered malware components to interact with the framework 
Initial attacks were largely focused on Russia and $HEX$ few other Eastern European countries 
However $NUM$ we have later seen that attackers are interested in targets all over the globe 
The framework is itself target-agnostic $NUM$ and seems highly automated 
The operational security exhibited by the attackers is very good $NUM$ among the best we have seen 
Although the attackers have left $HEX$ few clues $NUM$ we have been unable to provide attribution with any degree of accuracy 
The use of software vulnerabilities in order to execute malicious software on unsuspecting users $NUM$ computers is an important parameter to monitor 
This method of attack is not only known to have $HEX$ considerable success rate $NUM$ it is also often deployed by resourceful attackers and $NUM$ as such $NUM$ marks $HEX$ threat worth paying attention to 
The use of exploits in document formats like PDF $NUM$ DOC and RTF is in some ways especially noteworthy 
Documents are commonly exchanged via mail $NUM$ which make them perfect for email-borne targeted attacks $NUM$ what is otherwise known as spear phishing 
In March $NUM$ $NUM$ $NUM$ Microsoft published information about $HEX$ new vulnerability in Rich Text Format $NUM$ RTF $NUM$ 
This vulnerability $NUM$ named CVE-2014-1761 $NUM$ Microsoft Word RTF Object Confusion $NUM$ $NUM$ had already been used effectively by attackers at the time of the announcement 
$NUM$ previous vulnerabilities in the RTF file format $NUM$ known as CVE-2010-3333 and CVE-2012-0158 $NUM$ had become $NUM$ by that time $NUM$ mainstays of targeted attacks $NUM$ so we tracked how attackers implemented this new exploit with keen interest 
By late August $NUM$ we identified $HEX$ malware espionage operation that used both the CVE-2014-1761 and CVE-2012-0158 vulnerabilities to trigger execution of the malicious payload $NUM$ and which leveraged $HEX$ single cloud service as the backbone of its entire visible infrastructure 
When we examined the suspicious documents $NUM$ it was discovered that they were somewhat anomalous compared to the run-of-the-mill material 
Due to the many levels of obfuscation and indirection $NUM$ we named this the Inception framework $NUM$ but there ends all similarity with the movie by the same name 
Leonardo DiCaprio is not associated with this investigation

The following pages highlight $HEX$ representative selection of these documents 
All documents that we have found so far have been rather standard Word documents $NUM$ of the old $NUM$ compatible format based on OLE2 
Such documents can $NUM$ and typically do $NUM$ contain quite $HEX$ bit of metadata $NUM$ The name of the document creator $NUM$ the user who edited it most recently $NUM$ the name of the company whose copy of Word was used to create the document $NUM$ et al 
Users can optionally configure Word to remove this metadata when $HEX$ document is saved $NUM$ and that 's exactly what the creator of these documents did $NUM$ stripping out this potential source of attribution data 
However $NUM$ Word documents in this format contain additional information $NUM$ if you know where to look 
All Word documents of this format contain what 's known as $HEX$ File Information Block $NUM$ FIB $NUM$ 
The FIB contains information about the file 's internal structure $NUM$ and also $NUM$ to some extent $NUM$ data on the program used to create the file 
In the case of the samples we analyzed $NUM$ all of the documents were saved using the same build of Microsoft Word from Office14 $NUM$ better known as Office $NUM$ $NUM$ 
In addition $NUM$ documents can contain slack space in which old data remains 
For example $NUM$ the decoy that came with the attack named $NUM$ Organigrama Gobierno Rusia.doc $NUM$ contains Visual Basic leftovers indicating that it originally was created on $HEX$ computer that was configured to $HEX$ used by $HEX$ native Spanish speaker $NUM$ apparently by an advisor at the Spanish Embassy in Moscow 
Despite the limited information at our disposal about the targets of these attacks $NUM$ their content reveals some context about who the possible targets may have been 
The VBScript dropper code is also $HEX$ little unusual 
It declares $HEX$ Windows Management Instrumentation $NUM$ WMI $NUM$ object in order to reach components like the registry and file system 
$NUM$ is $HEX$ polymorphed dll file and the other $HEX$ binary data file with no obvious internal structure 
The names of these dropped files change from attack to attack 
Other names observed were $NUM$ The encrypted data files are named using random words apparently taken from $HEX$ dictionary $NUM$ $NUM$ acholias $NUM$ $NUM$ $NUM$ arzner $NUM$ $NUM$ $NUM$ bicorporate $NUM$ $NUM$ $NUM$ crockrell $NUM$ $NUM$ $NUM$ damnatorily $NUM$ etc 
Looking at $NUM$ of the dropped dlls we can see the authors originally called it 95Num3P3gm.dll.polymorphed.dll 
It is hard to describe the polymorphed dlls with any real depth $NUM$ as there is little consistency between them 
When $NUM$ nearly identical dlls are encoded using the polymorphic scheme there is very little code in common 
The call graphs are different and key functions have varying number of arguments 
The sizes of buffers allocated are also randomized to mask their intent 
What is common is that somewhere along the execution cycle is $NUM$ extremely large function $NUM$ over $NUM$ kb in length $NUM$ where early in $HEX$ large allocation is made where the un-obfuscated binary will $HEX$ placed 
The binary is then built from $HEX$ obfuscating segments of it that have been dispersed through the '.rdata $NUM$ section 
Simply halting execution before this function call permits $HEX$ researcher to extract the reconstructed DLL from memory 
Here $NUM$ pausing execution before the call to 'loadpefrommemory $NUM$ reveals the extracted PE at the memory address pointed to by $HEX$ 
This reconstructed DLL $NUM$ once loaded $NUM$ will decode $HEX$ configuration structure from its '.data $NUM$ section which contains $NUM$ important details $NUM$ the name of the encrypted data file dropped by the VBScript $NUM$ the AES key used to decrypt the file $NUM$ and the name of $HEX$ unique global mutex to hold while running to prevent multiple instances 
This turns out to $HEX$ yet another dll 
The first ordinal exported by this dll is located and then called $NUM$ passing in the configuration and the name of the encrypted file on disk as parameters 
This last dll is the heart of the threat $NUM$ originally called q5Byo.dll in this instance 
This file contains the true intent of this campaign 
WebDAV is $HEX$ communication standard that allows file management over HTTP or HTTPS 
Windows allows WebDAV sessions to $HEX$ mapped as network resources 
The use of WebDAV as the communication channel is atypical for most malware samples we see 
By using $HEX$ network resource $NUM$ the actual web traffic originates from the system itself $NUM$ and not from the process in which the malware resides 
All the authentication information for the WebDAV session including the URL $NUM$ folders $NUM$ path $NUM$ user name $NUM$ and password is stored within this last DLL in another AES-encrypted configuration structure in the binary 
$HEX$ unique path $NUM$ username $NUM$ and password were used for each malware instance we 've seen in the wild 
Also contained within the configuration structure is information on how to name the survey data on the remote file server 
The binary reads from its configuration $HEX$ string on how to generate the remote filename $NUM$ and $HEX$ list of extensions to use 
An example would $HEX$ $NUM$ 1-7d0-8s $NUM$ $NUM$ $NUM$ $NUM$ TIF $NUM$ $NUM$ $NUM$ TAR $NUM$ $NUM$ $NUM$ SIT $NUM$ $NUM$ which instructs the binary to generate $HEX$ filename with $NUM$ to $NUM$ numeric digit characters followed by $NUM$ to $NUM$ ASCII letters with $NUM$ of the $NUM$ listed extensions such as $NUM$ 664gher.TAR $NUM$ 
The cloud storage provider in every case we have seen was the Swedish company CloudMe.com $NUM$ which offers free and paid WebDAV cloud storage 
The URI model used by the malware is http $NUM$ $NUM$ $NUM$ username $NUM$ /CloudDrive/ which is $HEX$ direct reference to file storage 
It must $HEX$ noted that the CloudMe service is not actively spreading the malicious content $NUM$ the attackers are only using it for storing their files 
We notified CloudMe.com about the abuse of their services 
Their CEO $NUM$ Mr. Daniel Arthursson $NUM$ was none too happy about this $NUM$ and was very helpful in our further research

These indicate that there are many other accounts $NUM$ over $NUM$ $NUM$ likely related to this attack system 
We have no way of verifying this with absolute certainty $NUM$ but this is what we regard as $HEX$ high confidence assumption 
The cloud accounts are not used for one-way communication only 
$NUM$ such case is the franko7046 account $NUM$ used against the previously mentioned bank CEO 
This is how we found the depp3353 account 
In this new account there was another surprise waiting for us $NUM$ $HEX$ download folder with $NUM$ new encrypted files $NUM$ 921.bin and 922.bin 
Once decrypted $NUM$ these turned out to $HEX$ PE executables 
The $NUM$ new executables are plugins $NUM$ quite similar to each other and obviously compiled on the same setup 
Of interest $NUM$ both of the DLLs originally had the same internal name $NUM$ 78wO13YrJ0cB.dll $NUM$ 
Presumably the same PE sanitization script and parameters were used on both 
None of these plugins contain any means of CnC communication 
Neither are they ever written to disk 
This makes these modules extremely stealthy $NUM$ flexible and compatible with multiple toolsets independent of what CnC method is being used 
This model makes it possible to do the intrusion in steps $NUM$ with verification stages in between $NUM$ and the files will not $HEX$ easily found on affected computers 
Based on the information gathered from these modules $NUM$ the attackers appear to move to the next stage of their attack by placing more new components on the WebDAV shares 
Information about these uploads is limited by the fact that we do not have the AES keys to decrypt much of the uploaded data $NUM$ but we have been able to see some upload patterns 
What we assume to $HEX$ third-stage plugins appear on the shares as *.bin files of roughly 72kb 
However $NUM$ the next day $NUM$ another *.bin file of the same size will $HEX$ uploaded to the share 
This is $HEX$ pattern that repeats itself over all live accounts 
For Windows XP this will typically $HEX$ $NUM$ Microsoft-WebDAV-MiniRedir/5.1.2600 $NUM$ $NUM$ and for Windows $NUM$ $HEX$ common user-agent is $NUM$ Microsoft-WebDAV-MiniRedir/6.1.7601 $NUM$ 
Security researchers $NUM$ and there are $HEX$ few of them $NUM$ connect in $HEX$ variety of ways $NUM$ first of all $NUM$ we see $HEX$ number of connections that are indistinguishable from the way victims connect 
This happens when researchers use lab machines with live internet access to run the malware 
The only way we can tell these are researchers is because they connect from IP address ranges that are unlikely to $HEX$ victims $NUM$ and they also tend to consist of short-lived sessions 
Some researchers set up scheduled tasks to scan the shares for new updates and malware 
We see $HEX$ few variations of these $NUM$ $NUM$ typical configuration is where the requests contain $HEX$ Python-related user-agent string 
Attackers $NUM$ on the other hand $NUM$ do n't appear to use Windows 
We know these are not researchers $NUM$ because we can see malware files being uploaded by them $NUM$ We have $HEX$ log fragment in which the attackers uploaded $HEX$ sequential series of updates $NUM$ from 1746.bin to 1774.bin $NUM$ within $NUM$ hours on Sept 17th $NUM$ spread over $NUM$ different accounts and using $NUM$ different IP addresses in the process 
The user-agent string shows that attackers likely have used $HEX$ client based on the open source davfs2 file system for Linux to mount the WebDAV shares 
This client is used when uploading new malware $NUM$ but also when the attackers scan their shares for new victim updates $NUM$ in which case the shares are enumerated by requests in $HEX$ scheduled manner 
The attackers have used $HEX$ large number of IP addresses to access the shares 
As mentioned above $NUM$ there is $HEX$ rotation scheme in place in which $HEX$ new IP address will $HEX$ used after $HEX$ few minutes of access against CloudMe accounts 
These IP 's are distributed widely over geographical locations and service providers $NUM$ with $HEX$ heavy bias towards South Korean ranges 
At first we thought these IP 's belonged to some commercial proxy service $NUM$ particularly since several such proxy services also offer IP rotation 
However $NUM$ this turned out to $HEX$ $HEX$ wrong assumption 
$HEX$ superficial examination of the proxy IP addresses that connected to CloudMe showed them to $HEX$ internet-connected devices of various kinds 
Many were Korean Tera-EP home routers $NUM$ but there were several other products represented 
We were able to do some forensic work on $HEX$ compromised Tera-EP TE-800 device and discovered another dimension of the attacker 's infrastructure 
Under the ramfs mounted partition we found $HEX$ stripped and statically linked MIPS-el binary named tail- 
Instances of this were also found under the running process list 
Each sample of the binary we were able to acquire was configured with $HEX$ unique 32byte blowfish key and $HEX$ small $NUM$ encrypted section appended to the end of the binary 
This acts as $HEX$ management interface 
From here the attackers can request $HEX$ specific port to $HEX$ opened as $NUM$ of the following types $NUM$ SOCKET $NUM$ SOCKSS $NUM$ SOCKAT $NUM$ SOCKS5 $NUM$ or STATUSPORT 
To prevent anyone else from accessing this service all communication on the management interface is encrypted using the same blowfish key 
This setup makes it difficult to identify embedded devices compromised with this malware by scanning open ports 
In the wild we witnessed the attackers connect to the management port and request SOCKSS connections 
This would open the specified port and wait for configuration data $NUM$ which consists of $HEX$ domain name $NUM$ webdav.cloudme.com $NUM$ $NUM$ the destination port $NUM$ and $HEX$ variable length RC4 key $NUM$ all of which encrypted using the blowfish key

To illustrate $NUM$ we looked into another and more obscure timing factor $NUM$ The timing of the AES InitVector random seeds 
$HEX$ random seed is the initial value passed into $HEX$ pseudo-randomizer function 
The malware uses the random output to create what is known as an InitVector $NUM$ $HEX$ starting point for the AES encryption/decryption function 
The code used in some of the DLLs indicate that the attackers tend to use the $HEX$ time $NUM$ $NUM$ function to generate random seeds 
This function returns values of granularity down to seconds

Since we know the time window to $HEX$ within $HEX$ few days of the upload time we were able to brute force the time values that would generate the corresponding InitVectors
