The energy sector has become $HEX$ major focus for targeted attacks and is now among the top $NUM$ most targeted sectors worldwide 
Companies in the sector are facing $HEX$ growing risk of having their services interrupted or losing data 
The threat to energy firms is only likely to increase in the coming years as new developments $NUM$ such as further extensions of smart grids and smart metering expose more infrastructure to the Internet 
Equipment that is not connected to the Internet and other networks is not immune to threats and there has already been $HEX$ number of successful attacks against isolated systems 
Operators of critical infrastructure $NUM$ as well as energy utility companies $NUM$ need to $HEX$ aware of these threats and prepare accordingly 
The threat to energy firms comes from several different sources 
In some cases $NUM$ espionage from competitors is the primary motive $NUM$ with data on new projects $NUM$ exploration and finances being targeted 
Disruption and destruction are the goals of other attacks 
Some instances appear to $HEX$ state sponsored $NUM$ such as the disruption of the Iranian nuclear program by the Stuxnet worm in $NUM$ $NUM$ $NUM$ of the attacks that began this trend 
Others appear to $HEX$ the work of hacktivists with political or environmental agendas 
Internal attackers $NUM$ like disgruntled employees $NUM$ are also $HEX$ major source of attacks that often lead to service disruption 
The majority of the actors behind these attacks have grown more sophisticated in the way they attack 
During the monitoring period from July $NUM$ to June $NUM$ $NUM$ we observed an average of $NUM$ targeted attacks per day globally 
Of these $NUM$ $NUM$ attacks per day targeted the energy sector 
Accounting for $NUM$ percent of all attacks $NUM$ the energy sector was the second most targeted vertical in the last $NUM$ months of $NUM$ $NUM$ with only the government/public sector exceeding it with $NUM$ percent of all attacks 
The high ranking was mainly due to $HEX$ major attack against $HEX$ global oil company $NUM$ which we observed in September $NUM$ 
However $NUM$ in the first half of $NUM$ the energy sector continued to attract $HEX$ high proportion of attacks $NUM$ ranking in fifth place with $NUM$ percent of targeted attacks 
Not all of the attacks analyzed used highly sophisticated tools 
Most of them could have been prevented by following best practice guidelines for protecting the IT infrastructure and the industrial components $NUM$ indicating that despite high revenues and strategic importance $NUM$ many energy sector companies are not prioritizing cybersecurity 
The number of targeted cyberattacks in general has risen in the past few years 
In addition to this $NUM$ the rate of attack exposure has also risen $NUM$ with more companies becoming aware of attacks $NUM$ expecting them and searching for indications of compromise 
It is not $HEX$ new phenomenon $NUM$ but its importance has grown 
The Council on Foreign Relations $NUM$ $HEX$ US think tank $NUM$ reported that energy companies $NUM$ including oil and gas producers $NUM$ were often the focus of targeted attacks during summer $NUM$ 
In May $NUM$ the US Department of Homeland Security $NUM$ DHS $NUM$ warned of an increase in sabotage attacks against US energy companies located in the Middle East 
The government had tracked multiple attacks and issued $HEX$ warning together with the Industrial Control Systems Cyber Emergency Response Team $NUM$ ICS-CERT $NUM$ 
$HEX$ report by the US Congress supported this picture $NUM$ stating that many power utilities companies were under constant or daily attack through cyberspace 
Taking into account that successful breaches of critical infrastructures are still rare and that these numbers included generic malware infections $NUM$ it nevertheless highlights the potential for cyberattacks in the energy sector 
As in most sectors $NUM$ attackers are often after valuable information 
For example $NUM$ we have seen attackers target intellectual property such as technology for photovoltaic research and wind turbines $NUM$ or data on gas field exploration 
Information such as this is of high value and can generate huge profits for attackers or their sponsors 
The same information can also $HEX$ misused for an act of sabotage 
Many power utilities companies fear disruptive attacks the most $NUM$ regardless of whether it is done by internal or external attackers 
The energy sector has $HEX$ high potential for critical disruption through sabotage attacks 
Any interruption to the power grid would cause substantial chaos and cascading effects resulting in financial loss 
In the past there have been quite $HEX$ few attacks that included targets in the energy sector 
Some of these were more focused $NUM$ like Stuxnet $NUM$ Duqu $NUM$ Shamoon/Disttrack and Night Dragon 
Others saw power companies targeted among many other sectors $NUM$ such as Hidden Lynx $NUM$ Nitro $NUM$ Flamer $NUM$ Net Traveler and Elderwood to name $HEX$ few 
$NUM$ of the biggest examples $NUM$ and $HEX$ game changer for many organizations $NUM$ was Stuxnet 
This targeted sabotage attack $NUM$ which is believed to have been aimed against uranium enrichment facilities in Iran $NUM$ made clear what could $HEX$ done through cyberattacks 
For example $NUM$ such $HEX$ case happened in May $NUM$ $NUM$ when $HEX$ small fuel distribution company in North Carolina fell victim to $HEX$ cyberheist that transferred US $NUM$ $NUM$ from the company 's bank account 
Such threats spread broadly and might impact any person $NUM$ regardless of their employer 
These attackers aim at infecting as many computers as possible in order to maximize their chances of profits 
For this paper we focused on email data from targeted attacks between July $NUM$ and June $NUM$ 
Even though watering holes are becoming more frequently used in targeted attacks $NUM$ it is unfortunately quite difficult to reliably map these to individual campaigns 
$HEX$ blocked drive-by download attempt does not give any indication if it was $HEX$ targeted attack or just general noise 
In quite $HEX$ few cases we see the same common malware $NUM$ like Poison Ivy $NUM$ being used by generic attackers and by targeted attacks 
In such cases the sole difference between $HEX$ sophisticated targeted attack and $HEX$ generic one lies in the person commanding the malware 
Historically most industrial control systems $NUM$ ICS $NUM$ and supervisory control and data acquisition $NUM$ SCADA $NUM$ systems were in separated networks not connected to the Internet or any other network 
Unfortunately this security through segregation approach does not fully protect against cyberattacks 
In reality $NUM$ networks are rarely completely isolated 
Often some configuration updates are periodically installed or log files are transferred 
If systems are not directly connected $NUM$ the method of choice for these types of interactions is usually through $HEX$ USB stick or $HEX$ non-permanent modem connection $NUM$ which provides $HEX$ way into the restricted networks 
If networks are truly segregated $NUM$ this would mean that there would $HEX$ no software updates installed $NUM$ leaving old vulnerabilities open 
There are also issues around processes 
For example $NUM$ the revocation lists for digital certificates are seldom updated and therefore certificates which are no longer valid can not $HEX$ checked properly and would still $HEX$ accepted 
With the increasing desire for connectivity now reaching industrial plants $NUM$ many operators have started to connect their ICS to the Internet 
New adapters can bridge to older technology which was never intended to $HEX$ controlled over the Internet $NUM$ allowing it to $HEX$ connected easily 
This allows for efficient centralized monitoring and $NUM$ to some extent $NUM$ remote control of equipment 
Depending on the type of machinery controlled through the human-machine interface $NUM$ HMI $NUM$ of the ICS $NUM$ not all modifications are possible 
Some systems are physically connected in $HEX$ pure read-only mode for monitoring 
And even if they are fully connected $NUM$ some turbines have physical limitations or emergency systems based on physical effects that can not $HEX$ overridden by the digital controller 
Thus $NUM$ not all Hollywood scenarios of open flood gates or turbines that fly through the air are possible 
In the future $NUM$ more systems are going to implement the failsafe switches in software $NUM$ opening up the vector for malware attacks 
An additional source of concern is that some countries have started to open the energy market for smaller private contributors 
This means that almost anyone can use mini power plants like water $NUM$ wind or photovoltaic sites to $HEX$ energy back into the power grid 
Often these operators do not have $HEX$ full IT staff supporting the facilities at hand $NUM$ which might lead to more vulnerable installations 
Furthermore they may deploy new technology which might $HEX$ untested and contain some unknown vulnerabilities 
While these smaller sites make up only $HEX$ small portion of the grid $NUM$ new decentralized power input feeds are $HEX$ challenge for the balance of the power grid as well and need to $HEX$ carefully monitored 
Small outages or changes can have $HEX$ domino effect for the whole power grid 
To increase the exposure of energy firms even further $NUM$ sites like SHODAN $NUM$ which is essentially $HEX$ search engine for devices $NUM$ enable anyone to easily find exposed controllers on the Internet 
Of course not all of the industrial control systems connected to the Internet are critical systems or even real ones 
Some researchers have started to create honey pot systems in order to study the attackers $NUM$ which have apparently already attracted attackers like the Comment Crew/APT1 group $NUM$ who have broken into these decoy systems 
Smart grids and smart metering are bringing significant change to the world 's power systems 
Experts predict that billions of smart meters and sensors will $HEX$ installed worldwide over the next $NUM$ years 
They enable utility companies to measure energy consumption at $HEX$ more granular level $NUM$ creating better flow patterns and enabling different prices for consumption based on the time of day and location 
This development brings new opportunities $NUM$ as well as new challenges 
As with any connected infrastructure $NUM$ it is important to secure the network and its endpoint on multiple levels 
In addition to the issue of securing these devices $NUM$ smart grids will produce $HEX$ huge amount of data which $NUM$ depending on regulations $NUM$ will need to $HEX$ kept for audits 
Some of this data may $HEX$ sensitive and could raise privacy concerns if not properly protected 
This could easily grow to petabytes of data that needs to $HEX$ safely stored and managed 
It is beyond the scope of this paper to address all the challenges associated with smart grids and smart meters 
Symantec has created $HEX$ dedicated whitepaper for this topic $NUM$ How to protect critical infrastructure $NUM$ mitigate fraud and guarantee privacy 
As $HEX$ member of the CRISALIS project $NUM$ Symantec is following these developments closely and is helping to secure critical infrastructure together with partners from academia and different industry sectors 
There have been numerous cyberattacks against the energy sector over the past few years 
Not all of them were the work of sophisticated attackers $NUM$ some incidents were just collateral damage caused by malware infections or $HEX$ configuration issues 
These incidents highlight the fact that such attacks can happen and that they can have real life consequences 
In $NUM$ part of the Austrian and German power grid nearly broke down after $HEX$ control command was accidentally misdirected 
It is believed that $HEX$ status request command packet $NUM$ which was broadcast from $HEX$ German gas company as $HEX$ test for their newly installed network branch $NUM$ found its way into the systems of the Austrian energy power control and monitoring network 
Once there $NUM$ the message generated thousands of reply messages $NUM$ which generated even more data packages $NUM$ which in turn flooded the control network 
To stop this self-inflicted DDoS attack $NUM$ part of the monitoring and control network had to $HEX$ isolated and disconnected 
Fortunately the situation was resolved without any power outages 
In some cases the attacker tried to extort money from the energy companies $NUM$ threatening them with further blackouts 
Fortunately the power plant was already offline due to maintenance and the installed secondary backup monitoring system was unaffected by the worm 
Nevertheless the incident raised safety concerns 
The attack was not too sophisticated as it was easily spotted 
$HEX$ small modification of the PLC code instead would probably have gone unnoticed for $HEX$ long time 
In $NUM$ an attack took place against California 's power distribution center $NUM$ which controls the flow of electricity across California 
Due to apparently poor security configuration $NUM$ the attacker was able to compromise $NUM$ Web servers that were part of $HEX$ developer network and penetrate further from there 
Fortunately the attackers were stopped before they managed to attack any systems which were tied into the transmission grid for the Western United States 
According to Russian officials $NUM$ the largest natural gas extraction company in the country was successfully attacked in $NUM$ 
Through this switchboard $NUM$ the flow for individual gas pipelines could have been modified $NUM$ which would easily have caused widespread disruption 
Aside from these incidents $NUM$ there have also been $HEX$ number of more serious and well-documented targeted attacks against the energy sector $NUM$ The Stuxnet incident and its relatives Duqu $NUM$ Flamer and Gauss are some of the most talked-about cases of targeted attacks 
The first recorded appearance of what we now call Stuxnet version $NUM$ was in November $NUM$ 
Since then $NUM$ $HEX$ handful of different versions have been found and analyzed 
Stuxnet $HEX$ is based on what is now known as the $NUM$ tilded $NUM$ platform $NUM$ whereas Stuxnet $NUM$ is based on the Flamer framework 
The code segments and programming style differ $NUM$ which indicates that $NUM$ different programming teams were most likely responsible for the different branches of Stuxnet 
Thorough investigation into the mechanism and functions of this threat started in July $NUM$ 
The most notable vulnerability is the Microsoft Windows Shortcut 'LNK/PIF $NUM$ Files Automatic File Execution Vulnerability $NUM$ CVE-2010-2568 $NUM$ $NUM$ which allows it to auto-execute on USB drives 
This was most likely the first infection vector used by Stuxnet 
In the end $NUM$ Stuxnet propagated further than its authors probably intended 
We have monitored more than $NUM$ infected IP addresses in $NUM$ countries 
Many of those systems are most likely just collateral damage and were not intended to $HEX$ infected by the attackers 
For example multiple computers at Chevron were infected by Stuxnet $NUM$ without any damage being done 
Stuxnet 's payload focused on PLCs $NUM$ which are used to control different industrial components 
The target of the Stuxnet operation is believed to $HEX$ $HEX$ uranium enrichment facility in Iran 
Closing the valves at certain points in time would lead to an increase of pressure that could damage the equipment 
By speeding the centrifuges up and slowing them down repeatedly $NUM$ the output quality could $HEX$ spoiled and the centrifuges themselves could $HEX$ damaged 
This minimized the collateral damage at other facilities and showed that the attackers had in-depth knowledge of the targeted uranium enrichment facilities 
Operation Night Dragon $NUM$ which was uncovered in $NUM$ $NUM$ is $HEX$ typical example of global oil companies being targeted $NUM$ but this time not with the aim of disruption in mind 
The attackers did not use any zero-day vulnerabilities during their attacks 
Rather they used publicly available tools for each individual job 
In August $NUM$ an extremely destructive cyberattack hit an estimated $NUM$ computers at $NUM$ of the largest oil producers of the world in Saudi Arabia 
The W32.Disttrack malware used in this attack $NUM$ also known as Shamoon $NUM$ consists of $NUM$ components $NUM$ $HEX$ dropper $NUM$ $HEX$ wiper and $HEX$ reporter module 
The wiper component is only activated when $HEX$ hardcoded configuration date has been passed 
This enables $HEX$ coordinated $NUM$ $NUM$ time bomb $NUM$ scenario 
The malware does not contain any payload against ICS $NUM$ like Stuxnet does for PLCs $NUM$ and is not as sophisticated 
According to the company $NUM$ no computer related with the production or distribution of oil was affected $NUM$ since the operational network is separated and specially protected 
$NUM$ group that claimed responsibility for the attack posted on Pastebin that it was an anti-oppression hacker group

True or not $NUM$ this shows that it is not necessarily only state-sponsored attackers who are carrying out disruptive attacks 
Sabotage attacks usually fall into the orbit of hacktivists $NUM$ who seek attention rather than profit 
Some sources reported that the attackers had help from insiders $NUM$ which would explain the so far unclear infection vector 
Soon after this attack became known $NUM$ $HEX$ Qatari gas company was attacked in $HEX$ similar way 
The attacks are simple to carry out 
They often follow the same pattern $NUM$ starting with $HEX$ reconnaissance phase to gather all publicly available information 
The last phase may also involve $HEX$ disruption attack if the goal is sabotage 
For $HEX$ more detailed analysis of the attack phases $NUM$ see Appendix $HEX$ $HEX$ spear phishing attack consists of an email with either $HEX$ malicious attachment or $HEX$ link to $HEX$ malicious website 
Such emails are sent in bulk to $HEX$ handful of key users 
These waves are often repeated till enough people fall for the bait and compromise their computers 
For analysis on the social engineering themes used $NUM$ attack details and attachment types used $NUM$ see Appendix $HEX$ 
Some of the spear phishing campaigns are smaller in scale and are focused on specific targets 
For example $NUM$ on January $NUM$ $NUM$ $NUM$ $HEX$ global energy research company was targeted 
All receiving email addresses started with $HEX$ letter between G and R $NUM$ covering half of the alphabet 
Whether there was $HEX$ second wave of emails using the other half of the alphabet or whether the attackers only got their hands on part of the address book remains unknown 
All emails had either the subject line $NUM$ $NUM$ $NUM$ Obama QE4 $NUM$ Merry Christmas $NUM$ $NUM$ or $NUM$ $NUM$ $NUM$ Obama QE4 $NUM$ $NUM$ 
It is common to see spear phishing attacks take place around holidays $NUM$ as people are receiving more emails during these times and are less likely to perform due diligence while opening them 
The same family of dropper has been used in previous targeted attacks against other sectors $NUM$ indicating that $HEX$ group with multiple interests is behind the attacks 
$HEX$ week later $NUM$ on January $NUM$ $NUM$ $NUM$ $NUM$ the group attacked the same company again 
$NUM$ emails were sent to $NUM$ individuals using either $NUM$ $NUM$ NFL Playoffs Schedule $NUM$ or $NUM$ Re $NUM$ $NUM$ NFL Playoffs Schedule $NUM$ as $HEX$ subject line

$HEX$ global oil company $NUM$ with offices around the world $NUM$ had been under continuous attack for some time $NUM$ but in September $NUM$ we noticed an upsurge in activity $NUM$ with $NUM$ times more suspicious emails than on average

$NUM$ other people were targeted between $NUM$ and $NUM$ times $NUM$ many in the same region

These attacks can not $HEX$ attributed to only $NUM$ group or geographical region

For all regular client computers $NUM$ the well-established best practice guidelines apply

Securing and hardening of deployed operating systems with $HEX$ working strategy for patch deployment is important 
Reoccurring security awareness training can help users to identify social engineering attempts and prevent them from falling victim to them in the first place 
The company can perform penetration testing on Web and network applications but also on ICSs to identify and remedy any vulnerability 
For examples Web applications should $HEX$ tested against SQL injection attacks 
This can also help confirm if applied polices are followed through $NUM$ if the patch level is correct on all computers and if systems are compliant

In addition $NUM$ different layers of security products can help achieve better overall protection 
$NUM$ Security Information and Event Manager system $NUM$ SIEM $NUM$ $NUM$ Using $HEX$ SIEM can help correlate all related alerts in $NUM$ place 
This centralized view can $HEX$ cross referenced with threat intelligence data to generate prioritization and an action plan 
Painting the bigger picture of the overall security state can reveal previously unnoticed attacks 
For example failed login attempts on internal servers could indicate $HEX$ password breach 
This includes logging of critical systems and synchronization of time among multiple systems 
$NUM$ Ingress and egress filtering $NUM$ Filtering the network traffic with firewalls $NUM$ content filters and IPS allows the control of data flows 
This can prevent attackers from reaching internal systems 
It is important to also monitor outbound traffic $NUM$ as data exfiltration is $HEX$ key point for cyberespionage 
It should $HEX$ noted that with the increased use of cloud services and mobile devices $NUM$ some traffic might never pass through the company 's gateways 
Where traffic blocking is too disruptive at least monitoring should $HEX$ implemented 
$NUM$ Data loss prevention $NUM$ DLP $NUM$ $NUM$ DLP solutions can track the access and flow of critical information and prevent it from leaving the company or encrypt it automatically 
$NUM$ Endpoint protection $NUM$ Depending on the usage pattern of the computer $NUM$ different solutions are available to protect the endpoint 
Antivirus solution with proactive detection methods like behavioral analysis and reputation scanning can prevent unknown malware from installing itself 
HIPS $NUM$ host based intrusion prevention systems $NUM$ $NUM$ behavioral lockdown or whitelisting can protect computers from any kind of unwanted tampering without the need of constant updates 
$NUM$ System protection $NUM$ For non-standard IT systems $NUM$ hardening can increase the security 
On industrial systems which are not often updated or that can not $HEX$ updated $NUM$ exploitation can $HEX$ prevented with the help of lockdown solutions like Symantec Critical System Protection $NUM$ CSP $NUM$ 
Through policies $NUM$ only trusted system applications are allowed to run 
ICS should $HEX$ regularly checked and upgraded if new firmware exists 
Where this is not possible HIPS and behavioral lockdown tools can $HEX$ used to secure computers 
$NUM$ Email filtering $NUM$ Proper email filtering can prevent many spear phishing attempts from reaching users 
They can help minimize the risk of an untrained user falling for social engineering tricks 
$NUM$ Authentication $NUM$ Some of the ICS contain hardcoded passwords and $NUM$ wherever possible $NUM$ these should $HEX$ changed 
ICS frequently use weakly authenticated protocols that allow for impersonation attacks 
Where possible those authentication methods should $HEX$ upgraded or at least closely monitored 
Strong authentication or PKI should $HEX$ used where applicable 
Industrial control systems $NUM$ ICS $NUM$ should $HEX$ specially protected and monitored 
The control system and control network should $HEX$ secured 
Where possible $NUM$ ICS should $HEX$ separate from the Intranet 
Isolating these networks alone is often not enough to protect the control network $NUM$ but it can make it more difficult for attackers to succeed 
For some systems it can make sense to have $HEX$ plan to quickly disconnect or separate critical machines in the event of $HEX$ detected cyberattack

To identify $HEX$ series of targeted attacks that are likely performed by the same individuals $NUM$ we have used $HEX$ novel attack attribution methodology named TRIAGE 
Developed by Symantec Research Labs $NUM$ TRIAGE is data mining software that relies on multi-criteria decision analysis and intelligent data fusion algorithms to reliably link different attacks to the same source 
This framework has been developed in order to automate cyberintelligence tasks and reduce the time needed to get insights into organized cybercrime activities 
By enabling rapid analysis of large security data sets $NUM$ Symantec analysts can then quickly and more efficiently attribute various waves of cyberattacks to $HEX$ specific attack campaign likely run by the same individuals 
The TRIAGE framework was recently enhanced with novel visualizations thanks to VIS-SENSE $NUM$ $HEX$ European research project aiming at developing visual analytics technologies for network security applications 
Since its original conception $NUM$ TRIAGE has been successfully used to analyze the behavior of cybercriminals involved in various types of Internet attack activities $NUM$ such as rogue antivirus websites $NUM$ spam botnets operations $NUM$ scam campaigns and targeted attacks performed via spear phishing emails 
As with any other targeted attacks $NUM$ attacks against the energy sector often follow the same pattern 
It can $HEX$ broken down in different phases of attack 
It should $HEX$ noted that we have seen attackers modify their behavior and exceptions from the norm and this is possible especially if the target company has special circumstances or security measures in place 
During this phase the attacker tries to learn as much as possible about the targeted organization 
Information sources often include social networks $NUM$ job posting sites and press releases 
This enables the attacker to learn the contact details of possible target individuals as well as context that can $HEX$ used in social engineering scenarios 
The attacker will often create $HEX$ list of implemented security software used at the targeted company from whatever information is available 
These investigations often start completely passively without any direct contact with the company $NUM$ since there are many data sources publicly available 
Subsequently the attacker can use more interaction if needed 
Some attackers go through all the effort of creating $HEX$ fake social media account and befriending key employees 
After $HEX$ period of small talk $NUM$ to create $HEX$ false sense of security $NUM$ such $HEX$ connection can then $HEX$ used to pass on an infected document or find out about some key information 
Depending on the targeted location $NUM$ physical reconnaissance and eavesdropping may also $HEX$ used 
The actual break-in occurs during this phase 
There are $NUM$ main avenues of attack 
For example the Hidden Lynx group stopped using $HEX$ zero-day vulnerability in $HEX$ large watering hole attack after Microsoft released details on the vulnerability 
This helped to cover their activities and avoid unwanted attention 
For more difficult targets $NUM$ man-in-the-middle attacks can $HEX$ used 
Due to the complexity of such an attack $NUM$ they are rarely used 
Depending on the skills of the attacker and the time available $NUM$ the attacker might also attack systems at the perimeter $NUM$ such as Web servers $NUM$ and try to break in from there 
The malware used is not always sophisticated 
In these cases the person behind the malware orchestrating the commands is what makes the difference between $HEX$ targeted attack and $HEX$ broad generic infection 
Having said this $NUM$ on very unique targets $NUM$ we will often see the use of $HEX$ specifically designed piece malware $NUM$ such as in the case of Stuxnet 
Depending on the protection measures implemented by the target $NUM$ the attackers may also digitally sign their malware creation 
In the past there have been quite $HEX$ few cases where code signing certificates were stolen and later misused to sign malware in order to pass it unnoticed to high value targets 
Once the attacker has $HEX$ foothold on $NUM$ system $NUM$ the next step is to create $HEX$ plan for lateral movement through the network until the interesting data is found 
With watering hole attacks especially $NUM$ it can happen that computers that were not targeted get infected 
Infected computers need to $HEX$ assessed by the attacker and $NUM$ if necessary $NUM$ removed to keep the profile $NUM$ and with that the chances of exposure $NUM$ low 
Any account detail can $HEX$ useful to them 
Domain administrator passwords are of especially high value $NUM$ as they can help greatly in moving further through the Intranet 
Once new systems are identified the attacker will attempt to hop onto them as well 
This can either $HEX$ proprietary systems $NUM$ such as the case of Trojan.Jokra in South Korea $NUM$ or OS-specific $NUM$ such as hijacking Windows Update $NUM$ in the case of Flamer 
Especially in cases of wiping attacks $NUM$ such Trojan.Jokra $NUM$ this is $HEX$ very efficient way to disrupt as many computers as possible 
The capture and exfiltration phases are not always present 
If the sole goal of the attackers is to cause $HEX$ disruption they may directly jump to $HEX$ destructive payload 
However $NUM$ in most cases information is extracted first $NUM$ which in turn allows the sabotage to $HEX$ constructed more efficiently at $HEX$ later phase 
This can $HEX$ done with different levels of sophistication 
In addition to this $NUM$ the amount of data sent and the timing can $HEX$ chosen in $HEX$ smart way 
In some instances the infected computer might not have $HEX$ direct connection to the Internet 
This is when any destructive payload is launched 
If the attackers are only after information this phase might not happen at all 
The targets and the goals for disruption attacks can $HEX$ very different $NUM$ there is no such thing as one- size-fits-all for disruption attacks 
For example $NUM$ Stuxnet was tailored to attack $HEX$ specific uranium enrichment facility and would not work against $HEX$ different target 
In recent times $NUM$ wiper Trojans have been popular in attacks against the energy sector 
This can happen on any operating systems and we have seen scripts for different UNIX flavors being used as well

However $NUM$ there may still $HEX$ an outage while the computers are being restored

As $HEX$ 19-year-old young adult $NUM$ I was grateful to have survived but I had no idea how that single event would impact my future in such $HEX$ profound way

Our mission is simple $NUM$ to protect the world

$HEX$ major retaliation came in the form of $NUM$ 's Shamoon campaign $NUM$ which impacted RasGas and Saudi Aramco

When $HEX$ Windows kernel driver needs to allocate memory to store some type of data $NUM$ it creates so called kernel pools 
Such memory allocations have specific headers and tags that are used to identify the type of objects contained within the block 
For example such tags could $HEX$ Proc $NUM$ Thrd or File $NUM$ which respectively indicate that the given block would contain $HEX$ process $NUM$ thread or file object structure 
When performing forensic analysis of $HEX$ computer 's memory $NUM$ it is common to use $HEX$ technique called pool scanning to parse the kernel memory $NUM$ enumerate such kernel pools $NUM$ identify the type of content and extract it 
Just like Regin loader drivers $NUM$ this driver repeatedly uses the generic $NUM$ Ddk $NUM$ tag with ExAllocatePoolWithTag $NUM$ $NUM$ when allocating all kernel pools $NUM$ The generic tag which is used throughout the operating system when $HEX$ proper tag is not specified 
This makes it more difficult for forensic analysts to find any useful information when doing pool scanning $NUM$ since all its memory allocations will mix with many generic others 
Windows kernel drivers operate on different levels of priority $NUM$ from the lowest PASSIVELEVEL to the highest HIGHLEVEL 
This level is used by the processor to know what service give execution priority to and to make sure that the system does n't try to allocate used resources which could result in $HEX$ crash 
This technique is another example of the level of precaution the developers took while designing this malware framework

It looks for the tag $NUM$ $HEX$ $NUM$ $NUM$ $NUM$ $NUM$ on the page $NUM$ MiniDuke was searching for $NUM$ uri $NUM$ $NUM$ in previous samples $NUM$ and if the tag is found it decrypts $HEX$ URL from the data that follows it

Here is how the export address table of the patched binary looks after modifications 
When loaded $NUM$ TwitterJS instantiates the JScript COM object and decrypts $HEX$ JScript file containing the core logic of the module 
It first generates $HEX$ Twitter user to search for $NUM$ this search term changes every $NUM$ days and is actually $HEX$ match to the real account name $NUM$ not the Twitter account name 
The bot then visits the Twitter profiles returned by the search and looks for links that end with $NUM$ .xhtml $NUM$ 
When $NUM$ is found $NUM$ it replaces $NUM$ .xhtml $NUM$ with $NUM$ .php $NUM$ and fetches that link 
Information about the computer is embedded in the Accept HTTP header 
The first link on the retrieved page should contain base64 data $NUM$ the name attribute of the link is used as $HEX$ rolling XOR key to decrypt the JScript code 
Finally $NUM$ MiniDuke calculates $HEX$ hash of the fetched script and compares it with $HEX$ hardcoded hash in the TwitterJS script 
If they match $NUM$ the fetched script is executed by calling eval $NUM$ $NUM$ 
The code hashing algorithm used by the component looks very much like SHA-1 but outputs different hashes $NUM$ you can find the complete implementation in Appendix $HEX$ 
We decided to search for what was changed in the algorithm $NUM$ $NUM$ of our working hypotheses was that the algorithm might have been altered to make collisions feasible 
We could n't find an obvious difference $NUM$ all the constants and the steps of the algorithm were as expected 
Then we noticed that for short messages only the second 32-bit word was different when compared to the original SHA-1 
By examining how this 2nd word was generated we finally discovered that this was caused by $HEX$ scope issue 
As shown below the SHA-1 function used $HEX$ variable named $HEX$ $NUM$ the function Z $NUM$ $NUM$ is then called which also uses $HEX$ variable named $HEX$ without the var keyword $NUM$ causing it to $HEX$ treated as $HEX$ global variable rather than local to the function 
The end result is that the value of $HEX$ is also changed in the SHA-1 function which affects the value of the 2nd word for that round and ultimately the whole hash for long messages 
$HEX$ likely explanation of how this problem came to $HEX$ is that the variable names were changed to single letters using an automated tool prior to embedding it in the payload 
The $NUM$ $HEX$ variables probably had different names in the original script which avoided the issue 
So this leaves us with $NUM$ takeaways $NUM$ $NUM$ $NUM$ The difference in the hashing algorithm was unintentional and $NUM$ $NUM$ Always declare your local variables with the var keyword

The transition from patriotic hacking to cyber espionage is not an uncommon phenomenon 
It typically follows an increasing politicization within the hacking community $NUM$ particularly around geopolitical events 
This is followed by increasing links between the hacking community and the state $NUM$ particularly military and/or intelligence organizations 
In the late $NUM$ 's and early $NUM$ 's $NUM$ $HEX$ similar transition occurred within the Chinese hacking community 
Around this time $HEX$ significant shift in philosophy began to take place 
Members of the Chinese hacking community that participated in such attacks soon found that transitioning to cyber espionage was more rewarding-both in terms of developing $HEX$ more advanced skill set as well as in monetary remuneration 
$NUM$ group known as NCPH $NUM$ Network Crack Program Hacker $NUM$ $NUM$ whose founding member $NUM$ Wicked/Withered Rose $NUM$ was $HEX$ patriotic hacker $NUM$ made the transition to cyber espionage by founding $HEX$ $NUM$ hacker-for-hire $NUM$ group that simultaneously developed an association with the Chinese military 
The group began developing zero-day exploits $NUM$ rootkits and remote access tools $NUM$ RATs $NUM$ -using them in attacks against $HEX$ variety of targets including the U.S. Department of Defense 
$NUM$ $NUM$ of this group 's associates $NUM$ $NUM$ whg $NUM$ $NUM$ is still active and is believed to have developed $NUM$ variant of the PlugX/SOGU malware

In Iran $NUM$ the hacking community appears to $HEX$ undergoing $HEX$ similar transformation 
While $HEX$ variety of Iranian hacker groups had engaged in politically motivated website defacements $NUM$ the emergence of the $NUM$ Iranian Cyber Army $NUM$ in $NUM$ demonstrated $NUM$ $HEX$ concentrated effort to promote the Iranian government 's political narrative online $NUM$ 
They targeted $NUM$ among others $NUM$ news organizations $NUM$ opposition websites and social media 
This marked the beginning of $HEX$ large- scale cyber offensive against the perceived enemies of the Iranian government 
Foreign news and opposition websites are routinely blocked in Iran $NUM$ as are the tools that allow users in Iran to bypass these restrictions 
$NUM$ of the key stakeholders in Iran 's Internet censorship program is the Iranian Revolutionary Guard Corps $NUM$ IRGC $NUM$ $NUM$ under which the Basij paramilitary organization operates 
The Basij formed the Basij Cyber Council and actively recruits hackers in order to develop both defensive and offensive cyber capabilities 
There is increasing evidence to suggest that the hacker community in Iran is engaged in $HEX$ transition from politically motivated defacements and denial of service attacks to cyber espionage activities 
This model is consistent with the Basij 's recruitment of paramilitary volunteer hackers to $NUM$ engage in less complex hacking or infiltration operations $NUM$ leaving the more technical operations to entities over which they have increasingly direct control 
As such $NUM$ the capabilities of threat actors operating from Iran have traditionally been considered limited 
And unsurprisingly $NUM$ Iran has reportedly increased its efforts to improve offensive capabilities after being targeted by Stuxnet and Flame 
All Internet Service Providers $NUM$ ISPs $NUM$ in Iran are required to implement filtering technology that censors access to content which the Iranian government deems unacceptable 
This content includes categories such as pornography and political opposition 
In response to these restrictions $NUM$ Iranians have been increasingly using software that bypasses such filtering technology

In this edition we discuss the cyber landscape within the Democratic People's Republic of Korea 
The Democratic People 's Republic of Korea $NUM$ DPRK $NUM$ $NUM$ known in the West as North Korea $NUM$ is $HEX$ unique country with $HEX$ military-focused society and an unconventional technology infrastructure 
While North Korea was formerly on the U.S. list of state sponsors of terrorism $NUM$ it was removed in $NUM$ 
However $NUM$ due to North Korea 's hostility toward other nations $NUM$ its pursuit of nuclear weapons $NUM$ and human rights violations against its own citizens $NUM$ the United Nations and many Western entities have placed sanctions and embargoes against North Korea 
For example $NUM$ U.S. export laws forbid the sale of dual-use technologies $NUM$ or those that can $HEX$ used or repurposed for both civilian and military use $NUM$ to North Korea 
$NUM$ /n $NUM$ $NUM$ $NUM$ /fn $NUM$ Additionally $NUM$ the U.S. has $HEX$ military alliance with the Republic of Korea $NUM$ ROK $NUM$ $NUM$ known in the West as South Korea $NUM$ North Korea 's primary target of conflict 
Due to North Korea 's global interactions $NUM$ its cyber warfare capabilities are of particular interest to the U.S 
According to $HEX$ $NUM$ report by Major Steve Sin $NUM$ an intelligence analyst at U.S 
Forces Korea $NUM$ North Korean hackers have successfully penetrated U.S. defense networks more frequently than any other country that has targeted U.S. defense assets 
While Major Sin may have been overly optimistic about North Korea 's abilities $NUM$ it is clear that they should not $HEX$ underestimated 
Frank Cilluffo $NUM$ co-director of the Cyber Center for National and Economic Security at George Washington University $NUM$ testified before Congress that North Korea 's cyber capability $NUM$ poses an important 'wild card $NUM$ threat $NUM$ not only to the United States but also to the region and broader international stability… $NUM$ In an April $NUM$ testimony given to the House Armed Services Committee $NUM$ General Curtis M. Scaparrotti noted that $NUM$ North Korea remains $HEX$ significant threat to United States $NUM$ interests $NUM$ the security of South Korea $NUM$ and the international community due to its willingness to use force $NUM$ its continued development and proliferation of nuclear weapon and long- range ballistic missile programs $NUM$ and its abuse of its citizens $NUM$ human rights $NUM$ as well as the legitimate interests of its neighbors and the international community 
$NUM$ Scaparrotti stressed that $NUM$ While North Korea 's massive conventional forces have been declining due to aging and lack of resources…North Korea is emphasizing the development of its asymmetric capabilities 
North Korea 's asymmetric arsenal includes…an active cyber warfare capability 
$NUM$ While one would expect the regime 's digital infrastructure to also suffer from aging or lack of resources $NUM$ these factors do not take away from their technical abilities to wage cyber warfare 
While the U.S. views North Korea 's cyber warfare program as the regime 's foray into modern asymmetrical warfare $NUM$ South Korea views the regime 's cyber capabilities as $HEX$ terroristic threat $NUM$ $HEX$ build-up for an impending multifaceted attack 
It is important to note that $NUM$ to date $NUM$ no such attack has occurred 
According to $HEX$ report written by Captain Duk-Ki Kim $NUM$ Republic of Korea Navy officer and Ph.D. $NUM$ …the North Korean regime will first conduct $HEX$ simultaneous and multifarious cyber offensive on the Republic of Korea 's society and basic infrastructure $NUM$ government agencies $NUM$ and major military command centers while at the same time suppressing the ROK government and its domestic allies and supporters with nuclear weapons 
$NUM$ South Korea 's view of North Korea as $HEX$ terroristic threat may $HEX$ an attempt to downgrade North Korea politically $NUM$ since South Korea does not recognize the regime as $HEX$ legitimate state 
South Korean reports also claim that North Korea 's premier hacking unit $NUM$ Unit $NUM$ $NUM$ trails Russia and the U.S. as the world 's third largest cyber unit 
While this claim may $HEX$ exaggerated $NUM$ in $NUM$ $NUM$ South Korean reports estimated North Korea 's hacker forces at around $NUM$ personnel 
In $HEX$ July $NUM$ report from South Korea 's Yonhap News Agency $NUM$ that figure was upgraded to $NUM$ hacker elite 
We must stress that although these claims have not been corroborated $NUM$ South Korea has taken the regime 's cyber threats very seriously and is reportedly training $NUM$ personnel to defend against North Korean cyber attacks 
Obtaining details on North Korea 's cyber warfare capabilities is not an easy task 
This paper will examine the known cyber capabilities of North Korea 's regime and how the country maintains secrecy in these matters 
Through information obtained via open source intelligence $NUM$ OSINT $NUM$ $NUM$ we will present what is known about North Korea 's cyber warfare and supporting intelligence and psychological operations capabilities 
The following conditions proved to $HEX$ research roadblocks when gathering intelligence regarding North Korea 's cyber warfare capabilities $NUM$ $NUM$ Much of the intelligence available on North Korea is dated and may not accurately reflect the regime 's current capabilities 
$NUM$ Much of the intelligence available on North Korea comes from U.S. or South Korean military or agency reports 
These reports omit details that are likely classified $NUM$ such as specific IP addresses and individual actor information 
$NUM$ While South Korea is an ally of the United States $NUM$ its reports on North Korean cyber activity potentially contain incomplete or biased information 
Cultural factors that stem from $HEX$ history of tension and conflict between the $NUM$ nations may skew perception and make objectivity difficult 
$NUM$ North Korea 's Internet infrastructure and the regime 's strict control over its use ensures that there are no rogue actors and that all officially sanctioned actors exercise careful OPSEC and PERSEC practices in order to prevent inadvertent information leaks 
In other words $NUM$ there was no significant identifying information in the form of an OSINT trail left behind by the actors 
This hinders collection of original $NUM$ actionable threat intelligence and individual actor attribution 
$NUM$ North Korea is well-isolated from the outside world $NUM$ and its strong intelligence and psychological operations presence effectively creates confusion via counterintelligence and disinformation about the regime 's capabilities 
For this reason $NUM$ any $NUM$ official $NUM$ reports emanating from North Korea must $HEX$ taken with $HEX$ grain of salt 
This also hinders attempts to obtain original $NUM$ actionable threat intelligence 
In order for Westerners to understand the North Korean mindset $NUM$ it is necessary to examine the key components of North Korean political and ideological thought 
It is also necessary to provide $HEX$ brief explanation of how North Korea and South Korea view $NUM$ another $NUM$ in order to understand the basis for conflict between the $NUM$ 
North Korea has $NUM$ primary ideologies that provide context for the regime 's motivations and activities $NUM$ juche $NUM$ ju-cheh $NUM$ and songun $NUM$ sun-goon $NUM$ 
Juche is the official political ideology of North Korea 
It was instituted in $NUM$ and is based on the ideologies of Kim Il-Sung $NUM$ the founder of the DPRK 
Juche emphasizes self-reliance $NUM$ mastering revolution and reconstruction in one 's own country $NUM$ being independent of others $NUM$ displaying one 's strengths $NUM$ defending oneself $NUM$ and taking responsibility for solving one 's own problems 
North Korea 's air-gapped intranet $NUM$ described below $NUM$ exemplifies this philosophy in the country 's cyber infrastructure 
The juche philosophy explains North Korea 's disdain for outside cultural and political influence 
Juche challenges North Koreans to contribute to the regime 's chaju $NUM$ ja-ju $NUM$ $NUM$ $HEX$ concept of national sovereignty and independence 
The regime 's greatest fear is internal dissent and resulting destabilization 
In $HEX$ June $NUM$ Reddit AMA session $NUM$ Dr. Andrei Lankov $NUM$ an expert on North Korean culture and society $NUM$ noted $NUM$ there are also serious signs of public alienation and discontent 
And I can not rule out $HEX$ public outbreak of such discontent in the near future 
Of course $NUM$ if it happens $NUM$ it will have $HEX$ serious impact on the government 
$NUM$ Despite North Korea 's strong conviction in juche $NUM$ the regime collaborates with and receives support from other nations 
However $NUM$ due to this deep-seated ideology $NUM$ it is doubtful that North Korea fully trusts these apparent allies 
Later in this document $NUM$ we will show that North Korea relies heavily on China for Internet access 
North Korea also collaborates with China and Russia to train its cyber warriors and has longstanding political and military relationships with several nations 
Songun is North Korea 's $NUM$ military first $NUM$ doctrine 
Songun emphasizes the priority of the military in resource allocation and political and economic affairs 
This doctrine stems from the belief that the military is vital for preservation of chaju 
Understanding songun mindset gives context for this potential threat actor 's motivations 
According to $HEX$ $NUM$ Congressional report $NUM$ the strategy established under former leader Kim Jong-Il focused on $NUM$ internal security $NUM$ coercive diplomacy to compel acceptance of its diplomatic $NUM$ economic and security interests $NUM$ development of strategic military capabilities to deter external attack $NUM$ and challenging South Korea and the U.S.-South Korean alliance 
$NUM$ North Korea 's songun permeates the lives of all North Korean citizens 
Article $NUM$ of the North Korean Constitution states that the nation should base itself on $HEX$ nationwide defense system that includes all people 
North Korea $NUM$ with $HEX$ population of $NUM$ $NUM$ $NUM$ has an active duty force of $NUM$ $NUM$ personnel $NUM$ the fourth largest in the world 
The country 's reserve and paramilitary units comprise $NUM$ $NUM$ additional personnel 
In other words $NUM$ over $HEX$ third of the country's population serves in $HEX$ military or paramilitary capacity 
Some North Korean youth aged $NUM$ are inducted into the Korean Children 's Union 
The Korean Children 's Union is responsible for indoctrinating youths who pledge to build up their strength to later defend the regime 
Children aged $NUM$ can begin military training as members of the Young Red Guards $NUM$ $HEX$ paramilitary unit 
Beginning at age $NUM$ $NUM$ North Koreans are eligible to join the Reserve Military Training Unit 
The Reserve Military Training Unit forms the core of North Korea 's reserves and is typically assigned to the front or regional defense in wartime 
The youngest age at which $HEX$ citizen can $HEX$ conscripted for active duty is unclear $NUM$ reported ages range from $NUM$ 
Youths can volunteer for active duty service at age $NUM$ or $NUM$

The regime has an impressive number of conventional weapons $NUM$ considering the nation 's small land area and population size 
According to statistics released by CNN in $NUM$ $NUM$ North Korea's ground arsenal includes $NUM$ tanks $NUM$ $NUM$ armored vehicles $NUM$ and $NUM$ pieces of field artillery 
The regime 's sea weaponry includes $NUM$ submarines $NUM$ $NUM$ patrol combatants $NUM$ and $NUM$ amphibious landing craft 
Their airpower includes $NUM$ combat aircraft $NUM$ $NUM$ helicopters $NUM$ and $NUM$ transport aircraft 
While the limits of the regime 's ballistic missile program are unknown $NUM$ North Korea is thought to have fewer than $NUM$ short-range missiles and fewer than $NUM$ medium to long-range missiles 
However $NUM$ in recent years $NUM$ North Korea has suffered oil $NUM$ fuel $NUM$ electricity $NUM$ and food shortages 
Without aid from another entity $NUM$ the regime does not have sufficient resources to maintain and sustain the majority of its weapons and associated personnel for rapid deployment or prolonged combat 
Tension between North and South Korea has continued well past the armistice meant to end the Korean War 
Neither nation recognizes the other as $HEX$ legitimate state 
South Korea 's constitution legally defines South Korean territory as the entire Korean peninsula and its adjacent islands $NUM$ with $NUM$ North Korea $NUM$ being $HEX$ part of South Korea 
North Korea also claims to $HEX$ the sole government of the Korean Peninsula 
Each country 's claim of sovereignty and refusal to acknowledge the other as $HEX$ legitimate state creates the condition for perpetual conflict 
North Korea 's negative sentiment towards the U.S. stems from $NUM$ major factors $NUM$ the U.S. $NUM$ South Korea military alliance and North Korea 's perception that the U.S. is imperialistic and prone to exploitative capitalism 
In recent years $NUM$ $NUM$ primary factors have heavily influenced the current state of North Korea's relations with South Korea and her allies $NUM$ the rise of the regime 's leader Kim Jong Un and the inauguration of South Korean president Park Guen Hye 
Kim Jong Un officially rose to power in April $NUM$ $NUM$ following the death of his father Kim Jong Il in December $NUM$ 
While his age remained $HEX$ mystery for quite some time $NUM$ it was later revealed that he was born in January $NUM$ $NUM$ making him age $NUM$ at present 
This makes Kim Jong Un the world 's youngest leader of an established nation 
The young leader 's rise to power brought about several changes in North Korea 
First $NUM$ Kim Jong Un 's personal life is more public and more extravagant than that of his father 
Unlike his father $NUM$ the young Kim is often accompanied by his wife when making public appearances 
Second $NUM$ the young Kim $NUM$ who is more high-tech than his predecessor $NUM$ is reported to have an affinity for luxury items and is an avid gamer and basketball fan 
Third $NUM$ Kim Jong Un is more totalitarian than his father 
Following his rise to power $NUM$ the regime reportedly expanded its labor camps $NUM$ and more military resources were allocated to target those attempting to defect

These moves indicate the regime 's priority to deter internal destabilization and dissent $NUM$ which is perceived to $HEX$ $HEX$ greater threat than outside adversity 
According to Phil Robertson $NUM$ deputy Asia director at Human Rights Watch $NUM$ $NUM$ The government now recognizes that the accounts of escaping North Koreans reveal Pyongyang 's crimes $NUM$ so it is doing what it can to stop people from fleeing 
$NUM$ Under Kim Jong Un 's rule $NUM$ the regime has stepped up its nuclear materials production $NUM$ and the propaganda distributed by state media has become more menacing

North Korea 's cyber infrastructure is divided into $NUM$ major parts $NUM$ an outward-facing Internet connection and $HEX$ regime-controlled intranet 
North Korea 's outward-facing Internet connection is only available to select individuals and is closely monitored for any activity that is deemed anti- regime 
Individuals using the outward-facing Internet connection must $HEX$ authorized 
In $NUM$ $NUM$ Jean H. Lee $NUM$ the Associated Press bureau chief in Pyongyang $NUM$ stated that foreigners visiting North Korea are allowed Internet access with no firewalls 
Common citizens are limited to using the Kwangmyong $NUM$ gwang me-young $NUM$ $NUM$ $HEX$ nationwide intranet with no access to the world outside North Korea 
According to Lee $NUM$ Kwangmyong allows citizens $NUM$ access to the state media $NUM$ information sources that are vetted by the government $NUM$ and picked and pulled from the Internet and posted to their intranet site 
$NUM$ As of May $NUM$ $NUM$ North Korea had only $NUM$ $NUM$ Internet $HEX$ 
$NUM$ $HEX$ $NUM$ report from the Office of the National Counterintelligence Executive stated that North Korea 's $NUM$ Internet $HEX$ $NUM$ was $NUM$ the only place in North Korea for the public to access the Internet $NUM$ and that foreigners were allowed to access the Internet from this $HEX$

Star Joint Venture Co. is responsible for providing North Korea 's Internet access 
Star Joint Venture Co. was established by the Post and Telecommunications Corporation in cooperation with Loxley Pacific in Thailand 
In December $NUM$ $NUM$ Star Joint Venture became responsible for North Korea's Internet address allocation 
Previously $NUM$ Internet access was provided by $HEX$ German satellite link via Korea Computer Center Europe or via direct connections with China Netcom $NUM$ which was later merged into China Unicom 
By October $NUM$ $NUM$ North Korea had made its first known direct connection to the Internet $NUM$ hosting an outward-facing Korean Central News Agency website accessible from the global Internet 
However $NUM$ many of North Korea 's globally accessible websites are hosted in other countries 
In $NUM$ $NUM$ South Korean reports indicated that North Korea had joined the International Telecommunications Satellite Organization $NUM$ INTELSAT $NUM$ 
As of April $NUM$ $NUM$ North Korea reportedly used the Intelsat connection $NUM$ which appeared in border gateway protocol $NUM$ BGP $NUM$ announcements 
Some reports referred to the Intelsat connection as North Korea 's backup Internet connection $NUM$ in case the China Unicom connection fails 
$HEX$ March $NUM$ post on the blog rdns.im showed that North Korea no longer used the Intelsat connection 
In the blog post $NUM$ the author noted his method for proving that The Pirate Bay was not hosted in North Korea 
While his analysis of The Pirate Bay 's hosting is irrelevant to our research $NUM$ he did detail that $NUM$ always routes through AS4837 $NUM$ and AS131279 
AS131279 is Star-KP $NUM$ North Korea 's Star Joint Venture Company $NUM$ and AS4837 is China Unicom 
The author concluded that $NUM$ all $NUM$ traffic $NUM$ is ONLY routed through China Unicom and NOT through Intelsat

Korea Computer Center $NUM$ KCC $NUM$ is North Korea 's leading government research center for information technology 
KCC has eleven regional information centers and $NUM$ development and production centers 
Other countries with KCC branch offices include China $NUM$ Syria $NUM$ Germany $NUM$ and United Arab Emirates

North Korea 's proprietary operating system is Red Star OS 
The development of this Linux-based operating system started in $NUM$ 
Red Star OS is only offered in the Korean language and features proprietary software including Naenara $NUM$ $HEX$ Firefox-based browser $NUM$ $NUM$ as well as $HEX$ text editor $NUM$ email client $NUM$ audio and video players $NUM$ and games

At the top of North Korea 's military structure is the National Defense Commission $NUM$ NDC $NUM$ 
The NDC is also the highest branch of government and the regime 's supreme policymaking body 
Along with the Central Committee of the Workers $NUM$ Party of Korea and the Cabinet $NUM$ NDC is at the top of North Korea 's political hierarchy 
Article $NUM$ of North Korea 's Constitution gives the NDC the following powers $NUM$ $NUM$ The power to establish policies of the state in accordance with the military-first revolutionary line 
$NUM$ The power to guide the armed forces and oversee defense building 
$NUM$ The power to supervise and ensure the NDC and its chairman 's orders are executed and to establish necessary measures 
$NUM$ The power to override any state decisions or directives that are in opposition to the NDC or its chairman 's decisions and directives 
$NUM$ The power to create or remove central organs of the national defense sector 
$NUM$ The power to create and bestow military titles above general-grade officer rank 
The NDC oversees several defense and intelligence bodies including the Ministry of State Security $NUM$ the Ministry of People 's Security $NUM$ the Ministry of People 's Armed Forces $NUM$ and the Korean People's Army 
The Ministry of State Security $NUM$ MSS $NUM$ $NUM$ also known as the State Security Department $NUM$ is North Korea 's primary counterintelligence service 
It is considered an autonomous agent of the regime and reports directly to leader Kim Jong Un 
The MSS 's duties include oversight of North Korean prison camps $NUM$ investigation of domestic espionage $NUM$ repatriation of defectors $NUM$ and overseas counterespionage operations 
The Ministry of People 's Security is also known as the Ministry of Public Security $NUM$ MPS $NUM$ 
Focused on domestic order $NUM$ it oversees North Korea 's national police force $NUM$ conducts criminal investigations and preliminary examinations $NUM$ and oversees correctional facilities $NUM$ excluding prison camps 
While the roles of the MSS and MPS focus more on intelligence than on cyber operations $NUM$ the MSS also reportedly has $HEX$ communications monitoring and computer hacking group 
The Ministry of People 's Armed Forces $NUM$ MPAF $NUM$ administrates the Korean People 's Army $NUM$ KPA $NUM$ and oversees the General Staff Department $NUM$ GSD $NUM$ $NUM$ which is responsible for operational command and control of North Korea 's armed forces 
The General Staff Department also oversees the Reconnaissance General Bureau $NUM$ RGB $NUM$ $NUM$ North Korea 's agency for clandestine operations 
The RGB has $HEX$ role in both traditional and cyber operations 
In the past $NUM$ the RGB has sent agents on overseas military assistance missions to train insurgent groups 
The RGB reportedly has $HEX$ special operations forces $NUM$ SOF $NUM$ element and oversees $NUM$ bureaus that specialize in operations $NUM$ reconnaissance $NUM$ technology and cyber matters $NUM$ overseas intelligence collection $NUM$ inter-Korean talks $NUM$ and service support

It plays $HEX$ more traditional intelligence and psychological operations role $NUM$ rather than focusing on cyber operations 
The United Front Department $NUM$ UFD $NUM$ conducts overt operations to create pro-North Korean groups in South Korea 
Examples of this activity include the Korean Asia-Pacific Committee and the Ethnic Reconciliation Council 
The UFD also manages inter-Korean dialogue and North Korea's policy toward South Korea 
Its operations are also more traditional rather than cyber-focused 
The Liaison Department of the Worker 's Party oversees $HEX$ faction of ethnic North Koreans residing in Japan who are critical to North Korea 's cyber and intelligence programs 
This group $NUM$ which was established in $NUM$ $NUM$ is referred to by various names including the Chosen Soren $NUM$ Chongryon $NUM$ and the General Association of Korean Residents in Japan 
The Chongryon ascribe to juche and seek to preserve North Korean culture while living in Japan 
They operate North Korean style schools and refuse to assimilate with Japanese culture 
According to Mitsuhiro Suganuma $NUM$ former section head of the second intelligence department of the Japanese Public Security Intelligence Agency $NUM$ PSIA $NUM$ $NUM$ $NUM$ Chongryon is virtually under the direct control of the Liaison Department of the Workers $NUM$ Party of Korea $NUM$ which has been in charge of North Korea 's covert operations and underground activities against South Korea 
Chongryon in Japan has been $HEX$ strong support organization aimed at bringing $HEX$ revolution in South Korea $NUM$ or $HEX$ red unification by force 
$NUM$ He also stated $NUM$ North Korea will continue to make Chongryon serve as Pyongyang 's pawn in covert operations against South Korea 
$NUM$ The Chongryon are vital to North Korea 's military budget $NUM$ raising funds via weapons trafficking $NUM$ drug trafficking $NUM$ and other black market activities

$NUM$ example is Unikotech $NUM$ which was formed to sell KCC products abroad 
The Chongryon 's underground group known as the Gakushu-gumi $NUM$ or $NUM$ the study group $NUM$ $NUM$ gathers intelligence for North Korea and helps the regime procure advanced technologies 
The Chongryon 's role in North Korean intelligence and resource acquisition is discussed below in more detail 
The regime also has several government bodies under the Cabinet that oversee its infrastructure $NUM$ intelligence $NUM$ and technological development 
These include the Central Scientific and Technological Information Agency $NUM$ CSTIA $NUM$ $NUM$ the Ministry of Electronics Industry $NUM$ and the Ministry of Posts and Telecommunications 
The CSTIA collects $NUM$ analyzes $NUM$ and processes data regarding advanced science and technology then sends relevant information to appropriate areas of the national economy 
The amount of information contained in CSTIA's technical database makes it North Korea 's largest scientific facility 
According to $HEX$ CIA article $NUM$ review of CSTIA 's publications showed that China $NUM$ Russia $NUM$ and Japan are important sources of technical data 
CSTIA 's publications include newsletters and an 18-volume science and technology reference series 
The Ministry of Posts and Telecommunications is the body of oversight for Star Joint Venture Co. North Korea 's cyber warfare doctrine has not been clearly stated 
However $NUM$ based on cultural and technical observations $NUM$ we may deduce that North Korea 's cyber doctrine follows the tenets of juche nationalism and the songun doctrine 
Although North Korea 's limited online presence makes $HEX$ thorough analysis of their cyber warfare capabilities $HEX$ difficult task $NUM$ it must $HEX$ noted that what is known of those capabilities closely mirrors their kinetic warfare tactics 
Cyber warfare is simply the modern chapter in North Korea's long history of asymmetrical warfare 
North Korea has used various unconventional tactics in the past $NUM$ such as guerilla warfare $NUM$ strategic use of terrain $NUM$ and psychological operations 
The regime also aspires to create viable nuclear weapons 
Asymmetrical warfare is defined as $NUM$ $HEX$ conflict in which the resources of $NUM$ belligerents differ in essence and in the struggle $NUM$ interact and attempt to exploit each other 's characteristic weaknesses 
Such struggles often involve strategies and tactics of unconventional warfare $NUM$ the 'weaker $NUM$ combatants attempting to use strategy to offset deficiencies in quantity or quality $NUM$

It is interesting to note that much of North Korea 's cyber activity follows $HEX$ distinct pattern 
Analysis of North Korean cyber activity gives insight into these patterns and also helps tie together North Korea 's strategic $NUM$ tactical $NUM$ and operational capabilities 
Strategic capabilities refer to the assets used in support of $HEX$ long-term $NUM$ overarching goal 
Tactical capabilities refer to the methods and maneuvers actually implemented in pursuit of the strategic goal 
Operational capabilities refer to the potential use of these capabilities

Based on the information above $NUM$ we have identified strategic challenges that impact the development of North Korea 's cyber warfare capabilities 
We have also noted relevant implications $NUM$ $NUM$ The North Korean regime strictly controls all Internet infrastructure $NUM$ meaning cyber activity by dissidents or autonomous hacker groups are very unlikely 
In other words $NUM$ any cyber attacks originating in North Korea can $HEX$ assumed to $HEX$ state sponsored 
For this reason $NUM$ according to defectors $NUM$ the regime 's cyber operators do not typically launch attacks directly from within North Korea 
Instead $NUM$ many regime-sponsored attacks are launched from cells based in China $NUM$ U.S. $NUM$ South Asia $NUM$ Europe $NUM$ and even South Korea 
$NUM$ North Korea has $HEX$ limited number of outgoing connections 
For this reason $NUM$ there is $HEX$ low probability of DDoS originating from within 
However $NUM$ this does not preclude the use of botnets with $HEX$ local $HEX$ server or the use of networks in third-party nations to launch attacks 
As seen in the July $NUM$ attacks on South Korean and U.S. targets $NUM$ North Korea has leveraged networks in countries such as Austria $NUM$ Georgia $NUM$ Germany $NUM$ and even South Korea and the U.S. $NUM$ in order to launch cyber attacks 
North Korea will likely $HEX$ forced to rely on third parties for quite some time $NUM$ due to its lack of sufficient infrastructure for launching large-scale CNO 
$NUM$ Several outward facing websites are hosted in China and other countries 
This implies $NUM$ possibilities $NUM$ that North Korea 's infrastructure can not handle $HEX$ heavy incoming traffic load or that the regime wants to separate the propaganda crafted for an outside target audience from internally-focused propaganda 
This arrangement seems unlikely to change in the foreseeable future 
$NUM$ North Korea is known to have unstable power supplies $NUM$ which limits scalability of the regime 's current CNO capabilities 
This is another reason why expansion of CNO capabilities using the nation 's own infrastructure seems unlikely in the foreseeable future 
$NUM$ North Korea is known to have monetary deficiencies $NUM$ which further limit expansion of infrastructure and CNO capabilities $NUM$ at least without third-party aid 
North Korea continues to rely heavily on China for sustainment 
$NUM$ Although we see few instances of overt cyber operations $NUM$ that North Korea reportedly spends so much of its limited resources on training and equipping cyber operators speaks volumes 
The human element of the regime 's cyber war program $NUM$ at least $NUM$ has potential 
$NUM$ Sanctions against North Korea and export laws prohibit the sale of certain technologies to the regime 
In other words $NUM$ in order to obtain the technology needed for $HEX$ cyber warfare program $NUM$ the regime must improvise 
North Korea must develop its own technology $NUM$ manufacture technology using plans obtained via industrial espionage $NUM$ or rely on third parties to procure it for them 
However $NUM$ the regime has historically failed in its attempts of large-scale production of electronic components 
At present $NUM$ North Korea relies on China to provide much of its network hardware $NUM$ including servers and routers 
It is unlikely that North Korea will compromise on its nuclear program $NUM$ meaning sanctions will likely $HEX$ longstanding $NUM$ and the regime will have to continue to rely on third parties to procure technology

$NUM$ The attacks followed an explicit pattern $NUM$ most were around the time of U.S. $NUM$ South Korean joint military exercises $NUM$ while the others fell on $HEX$ significant date or were in response to political events

Does North Korea have sufficient cyber infrastructure and cyber warfare capabilities to harm the U.S. and its allies $NUM$ While North Korea 's cyber warfare capabilities pale in comparison to those of wealthier nations $NUM$ the regime has made significant progress in developing its infrastructure and in establishing cyber operations 
The rate of this progress warrants $HEX$ closer look at North Korea's motivations $NUM$ TTPs $NUM$ and capabilities 
As noted above $NUM$ North Korea views the U.S. and South Korea as its primary adversaries 
The U.S. and South Korea are high-tech nations with economies that depend heavily on technology 
In contrast $NUM$ North Korea does not have $HEX$ high tech culture 
For these reasons $NUM$ we should not overestimate the regime 's advanced cyber capability $NUM$ yet we should never underestimate the potential impact of North Korea utilizing less advanced $NUM$ quick-and-dirty tactics like DDoS to cripple their high-tech targets 
Both government and corporate entities are susceptible to being targeted by North Korean cyber attacks 
North Korean juche ideology places the survival of the regime as its primary goal $NUM$ and any perceived threat to the regime may $HEX$ targeted 
Several attacks on U.S. and South Korean government $NUM$ financial $NUM$ and critical infrastructure entities have been attributed to North Korean origins.. These attacks were often preceded by or occurred in conjunction with North Korea voicing negative sentiments about the targeted entities

The regime is extremely defensive and will $NUM$ in turn $NUM$ flex its muscles to show the world how capable it is $NUM$ even if this is an inaccurate display of their overall capabilities

The driver component of Gen $NUM$ and Gen $NUM$ are drastically different in their operation and intent 
For the Gen $NUM$ sub-family of Hikit $NUM$ the driver acts as $HEX$ NDIS $NUM$ network $NUM$ driver that is responsible for interfacing the DLL to the network while preventing $HEX$ direct WinSock interface from occurring 
The trigger string varies by Driver and DLL sample 
Gen $NUM$ uses $HEX$ standard client-server malware model meaning that the malware no longer requires $HEX$ direct Internet-facing network card $NUM$ no longer uses $HEX$ network driver for networking $NUM$ and provides the ability to network multiple Gen $NUM$ samples behind $HEX$ firewall with greater ease $NUM$ from the attacker's perspective $NUM$ 
The Gen $NUM$ sub-family $NUM$ however $NUM$ no longer employs network stealth provided by the Gen $NUM$ network driver which exposes the $HEX$ server addresses to analysts 
Each of the Hikit generations contains multiple sub-generations as the author $NUM$ s $NUM$ of Hikit have evolved their code over time 
There is $HEX$ noticeable steep improvement over the code base of Gen $NUM$ Hikit family during its $NUM$ development period 
The Gen $NUM$ sub-generations share $HEX$ similar improvement scale between late $NUM$ and late $NUM$ 
The earliest known Hikit sample dates back to $NUM$ March $NUM$ 
Known as the Gen $NUM$ sub-generation of Hikit Gen $NUM$ $NUM$ the first known sample of Hikit deviated from the later traditional Gen $NUM$ model 
The Gen $NUM$ sample was $HEX$ standalone executable whereas subsequent Gen $NUM$ sub-generations use $HEX$ DLL running as $HEX$ service 
The Gen $NUM$ sample is clearly $HEX$ work-in-progress 
The Gen $NUM$ sample $NUM$ while different than subsequent sub-generations $NUM$ does still rely on the Driver component and for the most part the structure of the code does not differ much going forward into the Gen $NUM$ evolution 
Less than $NUM$ weeks after Gen $NUM$ $NUM$ the author $NUM$ s $NUM$ of Hikit move into Gen $NUM$ 
The notable change is that the Hikit model of using $HEX$ DLL and driver $NUM$ which has remained until present day $NUM$ comes into being 
The code matures slightly between Gen $NUM$ and Gen $NUM$ but the functionality does not change 
Both Gen $NUM$ and Gen $NUM$ use plaintext data transmissions 
Development appears to halt on Gen $NUM$ for $NUM$ months between $NUM$ June $NUM$ and $NUM$ October $NUM$ based on $HEX$ lack of available samples found

Gen $NUM$ samples have Program Database $NUM$ PDB $NUM$ file strings that identify the file path of the Hikit source code 
For Gen $NUM$ and Gen $NUM$ samples $NUM$ the file path of the Hikit source code is consistently h $NUM$ $doubleSlash$ 
Starting with Gen $NUM$ $NUM$ the file path switches to $HEX$ $NUM$ $doubleSlash$ 
It is at this time that the functionality of Hikit Gen $NUM$ begins to mature 
$HEX$ more subtle change is the renaming of the $NUM$ socks5 $NUM$ command to simply $NUM$ proxy $NUM$ within the code 
The code within Hikit begins to mature but the overall functionality does not expand beyond the original set of commands found in Gen $NUM$ 
The other remarkable change within the Gen $NUM$ to Gen $NUM$ development is the way in which the session handshake trigger operates 
In Gen $NUM$ and Gen $NUM$ $NUM$ the DLL instructs the Driver to listen for $HEX$ specific string $NUM$ typically $HEX$ HTTP request string $NUM$ and responds with another string 
In Gen $NUM$ $NUM$ the Driver has $HEX$ hardcoded trigger string $NUM$ $HEX$ specific HTTP request string $NUM$ and the DLL instructs the Driver to inspect $HEX$ specific HTTP header field for $HEX$ specific hexadecimal value 
This moves Gen $NUM$ into more of $HEX$ username/password authentication scheme whereas previous sub-generations could potentially $HEX$ accessed by accidental HTTP requests 
At the same time $NUM$ the Driver responds with $HEX$ specific value with in the Etag HTTP header field 
This places Gen $NUM$ into $HEX$ more stealth position as $HEX$ random $NUM$ non-HTTP compliant response from Gen $NUM$ and Gen $NUM$ samples is more obvious than $HEX$ legitimate HTTP response with $HEX$ specially crafted Etag header 
Gen $NUM$ 's development cycle appears to exist between $NUM$ October $NUM$ and $NUM$ November $NUM$ with several new samples being found on the Internet having legitimate compile times during this time window 
There is $NUM$ however $NUM$ evidence that the development of Hikit Gen $NUM$ and Gen $NUM$ overlap by several months

The attackers behind the breach of the New York Times $NUM$ computer network late last year appear to $HEX$ mounting fresh assaults that leverage new and improved versions of malware

FireEye researchers spotted the malware when analyzing $HEX$ recent attempted attack on an organization involved in shaping economic policy 
The updates are significant for both of the longstanding malware families $NUM$ before this year $NUM$ Aumlib had not changed since at least May $NUM$ $NUM$ and Ixeshe had not evolved since at least December $NUM$ 
Cybercriminals are constantly evolving and adapting in their attempts to bypass computer network defenses 
But $NUM$ larger $NUM$ more successful threat actors tend to evolve at $HEX$ slower rate 
As long as these actors regularly achieve their objective $NUM$ stealing sensitive data $NUM$ $NUM$ they are not motivated to update or rethink their techniques $NUM$ tactics $NUM$ or procedures $NUM$ TTPs $NUM$ 
These threat actors $NUM$ tactics follow the same principles of evolution $NUM$ successful techniques propagate $NUM$ and unsuccessful ones are abandoned 
Attackers do not change their approach unless an external force or environmental shift compels them to 
As the old saying goes $NUM$ If it ai n't broke $NUM$ do n't fix it 
So when $HEX$ larger $NUM$ successful threat actor changes up tactics $NUM$ the move always piques our attention 
Naturally $NUM$ our first priority is ensuring that we detect the new or altered TTPs 
But we also attempt to figure out why the adversary changed $NUM$ what broke $NUM$ $NUM$ so that we can predict if and when they will change again in the future 
We observed an example of this phenomenon around May 
The previous versions of Aumlib had not changed since at least May $NUM$ $NUM$ and Ixeshe had not evolved since at least December $NUM$ 
We can not say for sure whether the attackers were responding to the scrutiny they received in the wake of the episode 
But we do know the change was sudden 
Akin to turning $HEX$ battleship $NUM$ retooling TTPs of large threat actors is formidable 
Such $HEX$ move requires recoding malware $NUM$ updating infrastructure $NUM$ and possibly retraining workers on new processes

Based on our observations $NUM$ the most successful threat actors evolve slowly and deliberately 
So when they do change $NUM$ pay close attention 
Knowing how attackers $NUM$ strategy is shifting is crucial to detecting and defending against today 's advanced threats 
But knowing the $NUM$ why $NUM$ is equally important 
That additional degree of understanding can help organizations forecast when and how $HEX$ threat actor might change their behavior $NUM$ because if you successfully foil their attacks $NUM$ they probably will
