Most of the content is legitimate ads 
Real-time $HEX$ networks are being used $NUM$ often unwittingly $NUM$ and some have taken steps to try and combat malicious use of their networks 
The Online Trust Alliance is $NUM$ such industry group comprised of major software companies and $HEX$ networks working together to try and address this problem 
Our goal in this paper is to shed light on the micro-targeting of companies by criminal enterprise employing real-time $HEX$ networks $NUM$ and to aid the industry in collectively addressing this problem 
Real-time $HEX$ bidding networks have evolved over the last $NUM$ years as $HEX$ means of micro-targeting customers with advertising content they are more likely to click-on 
From Wikipedia $NUM$ Real-time bidding $NUM$ RTB $NUM$ refers to the means by which $HEX$ inventory is bought and sold on $HEX$ per- impression basis $NUM$ via programmatic instantaneous auction $NUM$ similar to financial markets 
$NUM$ $NUM$ $NUM$ With real-time bidding $NUM$ advertising buyers bid on an impression and $NUM$ if the bid is won $NUM$ the buyer 's $HEX$ is instantly displayed on the publisher 's site 
$NUM$ $NUM$ $NUM$ Real-time bidding lets advertisers manage and optimize ads from multiple ad-networks by granting the user access to $HEX$ multitude of different networks $NUM$ allowing them to create and launch advertising campaigns $NUM$ prioritize networks and allocate advertising stock 
Real-time bidding is $HEX$ dynamic bidding process where each impression is bid for in $NUM$ near $NUM$ real time $NUM$ against $HEX$ static auction where the impressions are typically bundled in groups of $NUM$ 
$HEX$ typical transaction begins with $HEX$ user visiting $HEX$ website 
This triggers $HEX$ bid request that can include various pieces of data such as the user 's demographic information $NUM$ browsing history $NUM$ location $NUM$ and the page being loaded 
The request goes from the publisher to an $HEX$ exchange $NUM$ which submits it and the accompanying data to multiple advertisers who automatically submit bids in real time to place their ads 
Advertisers bid on each $HEX$ impression as it is served 
The impression goes to the highest bidder and their $HEX$ is served on the page.This process is repeated for every $HEX$ slot on the page 
Real time bidding transactions typically happen within $NUM$ milliseconds from the moment the $HEX$ exchange received the request 
The bidding happens autonomously and advertisers set maximum bids and budgets for an advertising campaign 
The criteria for bidding on particular types of consumers can $HEX$ very complex $NUM$ taking into account everything from very detailed behavioral profiles to conversion data 
The following infographic summarizes how advanced adversaries are now micro-targeting companies using malvertising 
The marketplace and auction of ads sounds great for actual ads 
The price to win the bid to push malvertising to any page you happen to visit ranges from $NUM$ to $NUM$ cents per impression 
$HEX$ malicious advertiser on $HEX$ network may serve crafted $NUM$ seemingly normal ads $NUM$ $HEX$ majority of the time 
In fact $NUM$ the ads are often stolen copies from legitimate advertisers 
This establishes the attacker 's legitimacy and trust on the $HEX$ network 
Of course with real-time $HEX$ bidding $NUM$ he can simply offer up low bids and his content would consistently lose in the marketplace 
Once the malvertiser detects that he has several infected hosts $NUM$ he removes the redirection code and goes back to serving standard $HEX$ banners 
He then $NUM$ burns $NUM$ his temporary exploit kit drop site $NUM$ moving his exploits to another location for $HEX$ new campaign 
This allows the malicious advertiser to perform hit and run attacks $NUM$ infect whomever he wants at whatever time he wants $NUM$ and maintain his presence on the advertising marketplace without drawing undue attention to his activities 
In the sections below $NUM$ we will provide highlights of the RTB industry $NUM$ its targeting capabilities $NUM$ and show how malvertisers have been mis-appropriating RTB networks to deliver malware 
The RTB $HEX$ networks provide significant micro-targeting capabilities that have long been used to serve legitimate content to users more likely to click on them 
In the following $NUM$ we describe these capabilities to show the state of the art in RTB network capabilities

$NUM$ Neustar does provide $HEX$ real-time bidding $HEX$ exchange $NUM$ but their real market is IP intelligence that they sell to other advertising networks for the purposes of better targeting specific users 
In Europe $NUM$ laws require that advertising networks allow people to opt out of having tracking cookies $NUM$ which is how many advertisers used to rely upon for $HEX$ campaign targeting

In $HEX$ blog post below $NUM$ Neustar boasts about their direct to IP range and enterprise advertising 
How can Neustar IP Intelligence target by IP $NUM$ While IP intelligence has been around for many years $NUM$ the ability to effectively target advertising by audience $NUM$ based on IP is very new 
Neustar IP Intelligence is currently working with select DSP platforms to buy impressions off of the exchanges based on the IP address rather than cookies 
This has only been possible with the recent emergence of real time bidding $NUM$ RTB $NUM$ 
The secret sauce is in understanding the IP and the methodology necessary for targeting ads appropriately against it 
Is an IP Address like $HEX$ cookie $NUM$ No $NUM$ an IP address only identifies devices on $HEX$ network 
The IP address does not contain any PII and does not track or store any consumer usage or behavioral information 
$NUM$ But IP ranges are registered by IANA $NUM$ and you can easily know who owns the ranges $NUM$ Product Specific Questions Q1 $NUM$ How does the process work $NUM$ The process works exactly like any advertising network 
Instead of buying inventory based on $HEX$ cookie $NUM$ Neustar is buying inventory based on an IP address 
We run the targeting specifics against our proprietary database and create $HEX$ custom IP list to target against 
Neustar has set up relationships with partners that have built the functionality for this to work end-to-end for our advertisers 
Neustar offers $HEX$ full service $HEX$ network 
Brand marketers who wish to advertise using IP Audience Targeting can work directly with Neustar to determine custom IP placements $NUM$ run campaigns $NUM$ optimization $NUM$ reporting and billing 
Much like any traditional online publisher or online $HEX$ network $NUM$ Neustar manages the entire process 
How does Neustar deliver its ads $NUM$ We use industry standard methods for delivering our ads $NUM$ but what makes our approach special is that we bake in the IP data before delivering the inventory with our network partners $NUM$ which allows us to target display $HEX$ campaigns to $HEX$ specific business or organization 
We obtain inventory from $HEX$ exchanges $NUM$ but have our own $HEX$ server

Most RTB $HEX$ providers allow for advertisers to host their own $HEX$ content

Naturally this piqued our interest $NUM$ so we decided to peer down the rabbit hole 
Suffice to say $NUM$ the hole was $HEX$ lot deeper than we expected $NUM$ In fact $NUM$ it went all the way back to the notorious Russian APT family MiniDuke $NUM$ known to have been used in targeted attacks against NATO and European government agencies 
The malware used in this case is $NUM$ however $NUM$ not $HEX$ version of MiniDuke 
It is instead $HEX$ separate $NUM$ distinct family of malware that we have since taken to calling OnionDuke 
But lets start from the beginning 
When $HEX$ user attempts to download an executable via the malicious Tor exit node $NUM$ what they actually receive is an executable $NUM$ wrapper $NUM$ that embeds both the original executable and $HEX$ second $NUM$ malicious executable 
Upon execution $NUM$ the wrapper will proceed to write to disk and execute the original executable $NUM$ thereby tricking the user into believing that everything went fine 
However $NUM$ the wrapper will also write to disk and execute the second executable 
In all the cases we have observed $NUM$ this malicious executable has been the same binary $NUM$ SHA1 $NUM$ $HEX$ $NUM$ detected as Trojan-Dropper $NUM$ W32/OnionDuke.A $NUM$ 
In reality $NUM$ the resource is actually an encrypted dynamically linked library $NUM$ DLL $NUM$ file 
It should $HEX$ noted $NUM$ that we believe all $NUM$ domains contacted by the malware are innocent websites compromised by the malware operators $NUM$ not dedicated malicious servers 
Through our research $NUM$ we have also been able to identify multiple other components of the OnionDuke malware family 
$NUM$ component $NUM$ however $NUM$ is an interesting exception 
What makes the overpict.com domain interesting $NUM$ is it was originally registered in $NUM$ with the alias of $NUM$ John Kasai $NUM$ 
Within $HEX$ two-week window $NUM$ $NUM$ John Kasai $NUM$ also registered the following domains $NUM$ airtravelabroad.com $NUM$ beijingnewsblog.net $NUM$ grouptumbler.com $NUM$ leveldelta.com $NUM$ nasdaqblog.net $NUM$ natureinhome.com $NUM$ nestedmail.com $NUM$ nostressjob.com $NUM$ nytunion.com $NUM$ oilnewsblog.com $NUM$ sixsquare.net and ustradecomp.com 
This strongly suggests that although OnionDuke and MiniDuke are $NUM$ separate families of malware $NUM$ the actors behind them are connected through the use of shared infrastructure 
However $NUM$ it would seem that the OnionDuke family is much older $NUM$ both based on older compilation timestamps and also on the fact that some of the embedded configuration data make reference to an apparent version number of $NUM$ suggesting that at least $NUM$ earlier versions of the family exist 
During our research $NUM$ we have also uncovered strong evidence suggesting that OnionDuke has been used in targeted attacks against European government agencies $NUM$ although we have so far been unable to identify the infection vector $NUM$ s $NUM$ 
Interestingly $NUM$ this would suggest $NUM$ very different targeting strategies 
On $NUM$ hand is the $NUM$ shooting $HEX$ fly with $HEX$ cannon $NUM$ mass-infection strategy through modified binaries and $NUM$ on the other $NUM$ the more surgical targeting traditionally associated with APT operations 
In any case $NUM$ although much is still shrouded in mystery and speculation $NUM$ $NUM$ thing is certain 
While using Tor may help you stay anonymous $NUM$ it does at the same time paint $HEX$ huge target on your back 
It 's never $HEX$ good idea to download binaries via Tor $NUM$ or anything else $NUM$ without encryption 
The problem with Tor is that you have no idea who is maintaining the exit node you are using and what their motives are 
VPNs $NUM$ such as our Freedome VPN $NUM$ will encrypt your connection all the way through the Tor network $NUM$ so the maintainers of Tor exit nodes will not see your traffic and $HEX$ n't tamper with it 
As the pro-democracy movement in Hong Kong has continued $NUM$ we 've been watching for indications of confrontation taking place in cyberspace 
Protests began in September and have continued to escalate 
Additionally $NUM$ at least $NUM$ member of the popular online forum HKGolden was arrested for posting messages encouraging support for the OccupyCentral Pro Democracy movement 
The use of DDoS attacks as $HEX$ political tool during times of conflict is not new $NUM$ patriotic hacktivist groups frequently use them as $HEX$ means to stifle political activity of which they disapprove 
The question of state sponsorship $NUM$ or at least tacit approval $NUM$ in online crackdowns is often up for debate and ambiguous from $HEX$ technical evidence and tradecraft perspective 
In this case $NUM$ however $NUM$ we 've discovered an overlap in the tools and infrastructure used by China-based advanced persistent threat $NUM$ APT $NUM$ actors and the DDoS attack activity 
We believe that these DDoS attacks are linked to previously observed APT activity $NUM$ including Operation Poisoned Hurricane 
This correlation sheds light on the potential relationships $NUM$ symbiosis and tool sharing between patriotic hacker activities designed to disrupt anti-government activists in China $NUM$ and the APT activity we consistently see that is more IP theft and espionage-focused

The most direct connection between these DDoS attacks and previous APT activity is the use of the QTI International and CallTogether code signing certificates $NUM$ which we have seen in malware attributed to APT activity

As Brandon Dixon noted here $NUM$ the java-sec $NUM$ 
$NUM$ com domain is linked to the java- se $NUM$ 
$NUM$ com by shared hosting history at the following IP address $NUM$ It is unclear why these actors would attack an IP address they were actively using 
It 's possible that the attackers wanted to test their botnet 's capability by attacking an IP they were using to gather statistics on the size of the attack 
It is also possible that the attackers simply made $HEX$ mistake and accidentally issued commands to attack their own infrastructure 
While not conclusive $NUM$ the evidence presented above shows $HEX$ link between confirmed APT activity and ongoing DDoS attacks that appear to $HEX$ designed to silence the Pro Democracy movement in Hong Kong 
The evidence does not conclusively prove that the same actors responsible for the DDoS attacks are also behind the observed intrusion activity discussed above $NUM$ such as Operation Poisoned Hurricane 
Rather $NUM$ the evidence may indicate that $HEX$ common quartermaster supports both the DDoS attacks and ongoing intrusion activity 
In either scenario $NUM$ there is $HEX$ clear connection between the intrusion activity documented in Operation Poisoned Hurricane and the DDOS attacks documented here 
While the tactics of these activities are very different from $HEX$ technical perspective $NUM$ each supports distinct political objectives 
Operation Poisoned Hurricane 's objective appeared to have in part been IP theft possibly for economic gain or other competitive advantages 
In the DDOS attacks $NUM$ the objective was to silence free speech and suppress the pro democracy movement in Hong Kong 
The Chinese government is the entity most likely to $HEX$ interested in achieving both of these objectives

$NUM$ of the questions which comes up in the months after big security whitepaper disclosures is $NUM$ where are they now $NUM$ In other words $NUM$ what happened to the operators $NUM$ tools $NUM$ and infrastructure which was revealed in the reports $NUM$ blog-posts $NUM$ and press interviews 
Did they continue on as before $NUM$ did they re-build the disclosed infrastructure and tools $NUM$ did they go away and get jobs in another line of work $NUM$ In some cases $NUM$ the disclosure had little $NUM$ if any impact on the operation 
For example $NUM$ after the McAfee ShadyRAT report in $NUM$ $NUM$ there was absolutely no change in the attacks from the group behind this 
However $NUM$ when Mandiant released their APT1 report in $NUM$ $NUM$ there was $HEX$ noticeable reduction in activity from the group $NUM$ and much of the tools and infrastructure has not been seen since 
In the September $NUM$ issue of Foreign Affairs magazine $NUM$ former US Deputy Secretary of Defense William J. Lynn discussed $HEX$ cyber-attack which happened $NUM$ years previously on the DoD's classified computer networks 
Lynn described how $HEX$ foreign intelligence agency planted malicious code on the networks with the aim of transferring data to servers under their control 
The article included the now oft-quoted phrase 'digital beachhead $NUM$ to describe what was undoubtedly $HEX$ significant compromise of US military systems 
Further reports in the press kept the story alive in $NUM$ $NUM$ but since then this threat has received remarkably little attention 
However $NUM$ the operation behind the attacks has continued with little modification to the tools and techniques $NUM$ in spite of the widespread attention $HEX$ few years ago 
There are some threats which come and go $NUM$ whilst there are others which are permanent features of the landscape 
In this paper $NUM$ we describe the tools and techniques of $NUM$ of the most sophisticated and persistent threats we track 
We hope this will help victims identify intrusions and understand their need to improve defences 
Cyber security is $HEX$ collaborative effort $NUM$ the operation described in this paper again raises the bar for the security community in their efforts to keep up with the attackers in cyber-space 
When antivirus back-end classification platforms can not identify $HEX$ malware family for an analysed malicious sample $NUM$ they assign generic names $NUM$ such as $NUM$ Trojan Horse $NUM$ or $NUM$ Agent $NUM$ 
The variant letters are also assigned automatically $NUM$ by using hexavigesimal $NUM$ or Base26 $NUM$ notation 
That is $NUM$ the variant letters are auto-assigned starting from $NUM$ $HEX$ $NUM$ $NUM$ followed with $NUM$ $HEX$ $NUM$ $NUM$ and so on until $NUM$ Z $NUM$ 
Next comes $NUM$ $HEX$ $NUM$ $NUM$ $NUM$ $HEX$ $NUM$ and so on $NUM$ until $NUM$ ZZ $NUM$ 
After that $NUM$ the variant letters start from $NUM$ $HEX$ $NUM$ $NUM$ $NUM$ $HEX$ $NUM$ and so on $NUM$ until $NUM$ ZZZ $NUM$ 
Back in $NUM$ an unknown malicious file was discovered and auto-classified as $NUM$ Agent.BTZ $NUM$ $NUM$ meaning it was registered as unknown malicious sample $NUM$ $NUM$ in an anti-virus classification system 
It was n't given an actual name $NUM$ only $HEX$ generic $NUM$ 
Meanwhile $NUM$ internally the authors behind this malware were using their own naming systems $NUM$ with specific titles for their file components and projects such as $NUM$ snake $NUM$ $NUM$ $NUM$ uroburos $NUM$ $NUM$ $NUM$ sengoku $NUM$ $NUM$ and $NUM$ snark $NUM$ used to denote variants of their framework

Snake 's architecture turned out to $HEX$ quite interesting 
In general $NUM$ its operation relies on kernel mode drivers $NUM$ making it $HEX$ rootkit 
At the same time $NUM$ Snake exposed $HEX$ flexibility to conduct its operations by engaging these noticeably different architectures 
the area of the computer system where application software executes 
the area where lower level system code such as device drivers run 
In both architectures $NUM$ there is both 32-bit and 64-bit code involved 
In order to distinguish between these architectures $NUM$ we will call them the usermode-centric and the kernel-centric architectures respectively 
The remainder of this report gives $HEX$ detailed explanation of how the $NUM$ Snake architectures embed themselves in the target system and communicate with the outside world 
We have also provided $HEX$ set of technical indicators in the Appendix to enable organisations and the security research community to identify compromises 
In total we have collected over $NUM$ unique files related to this espionage toolkit 
Many of these were submitted to online malware analysis websites by victims and investigators over several years 
In many cases the source country information of the submission is available 
These allow us to visualise the distribution of countries where this malware has been seen $NUM$ Whilst this view is likely to only $HEX$ the tip of the iceberg $NUM$ it does give us an initial insight into the profile of targets for the Snake operations

Similarly $NUM$ plotting the hour of the day in which the samples were compiled reveals another human pattern $NUM$ the working day 
This has been adjusted to UTC+4 to show $HEX$ possible fit to the operators $NUM$ local time

By communicating from within $HEX$ process that also communicates $NUM$ even $HEX$ technically savvy user will find it challenging to detect Snake traffic among legitimate traffic 
The reason behind such difficulty is because modern web pages often fetch pages from the different web servers $NUM$ including such data as additional scripts $NUM$ CSS templates $NUM$ advertising contents $NUM$ analytics data $NUM$ blogs $NUM$ social networking data $NUM$ etc 
When intercepted with the purpose of analysis $NUM$ such traffic may literally represent itself hundreds of DNS and HTTP requests made when $HEX$ popular website $NUM$ such as $HEX$ news website is open 
In order to test Snake 's communications with the $HEX$ $NUM$ $HEX$ servers $NUM$ and still being able to clearly distinguish its traffic $NUM$ $HEX$ small tool was built to generate GET request to $HEX$ web server running on the analysed system 
The tool was named as chrome.exe in order to trigger the malware communications 
As long as the test tool named chrome.exe did not make any requests $NUM$ its memory stayed pristine 
There were no injections made by the driver 
For example $NUM$ Snake 's home directory could $HEX$ $HEX$ $NUM$ $doubleSlash$ $NUM$ NtUninstallQ812589 $NUM$ 
Memory pipes is $HEX$ common mechanism for Inter-Process Communications $NUM$ IPC $NUM$ 
When the pipe server reads such requests from the pipes $NUM$ it performs the web request on behalf of $HEX$ client by using WinINet APIs $NUM$ so it effectively serves as $HEX$ proxy 
Pipe server is $HEX$ special mode of the injected DLL 
In its communication protocol with the driver it uses the IOCTL code of $HEX$ 
However $NUM$ the data appears to $HEX$ defined in the structures $NUM$ so it is very likely the DLL could $HEX$ generated by $HEX$ stand-alone builder that 'patches $NUM$ the DLL with the new/updated list of $HEX$ $NUM$ $HEX$ 
by using the reconnaissance tool that is explained later $NUM$ 
The dropper itself is 32-bit $NUM$ so it will run both on 32-bit and 64-bit Windows OS $NUM$ in WoW64 mode $NUM$

Other samples may have $HEX$ different registration name $NUM$ such as ~ROOT 
TDI is considered deprecated and will $HEX$ removed in future versions of Microsoft Windows $NUM$ but it 's still supported on Windows $NUM$

For SMTP traffic $NUM$ it communicates back normal SMTP server responses $NUM$ such as $NUM$ $NUM$ Sender OK $NUM$ $NUM$ $NUM$ $NUM$ $HEX$ sequence of commands $NUM$ $NUM$ etc 
Another opportunity this mode unlocks is $HEX$ peer-to-peer network mode with no centralised $HEX$ $NUM$ $HEX$

Thus $NUM$ it is not possible to reveal the contents of the Snake 's volume by accessing the contents of this file $NUM$ unless the encryption is broken $NUM$ that is $NUM$

to pass commands $NUM$ configuration parameters $NUM$ binary images of additional Snake components 
The 64-bit version of Snake must deal with $HEX$ number of additional security protections implemented in 64-bit editions of Microsoft Windows $NUM$ the most significant of which are kernel driver signature validation and Kernel Patch Protection $NUM$ more commonly known as PatchGuard $NUM$ 
PatchGuard is $HEX$ feature of 64-bit Windows which aims to prevent modification of the Windows kernel $NUM$ something that is often performed by malware attempting to hide itself on an infected system 
Although PatchGuard is successful at preventing kernel patching once initialised $NUM$ several published bypass approaches exist $NUM$ 
The technique used by Snake appears to $HEX$ similar to these approaches 
The driver signing policy enforced by all 64-bit versions of Windows from Vista onwards requires all kernel-mode drivers to $HEX$ signed with $HEX$ valid digital signature 
Does it resort to using bootkit technology $NUM$ which has been used in the past to bypass protections to load unsigned 64-bit drivers $NUM$ The answer $NUM$ No 
Bootkits must overwrite the Master Boot Record $NUM$ MBR $NUM$ and antivirus products are well trained to catch that kind of $HEX$ behavior 
The masterminds behind Snake rootkit seem to $HEX$ well aware of this so what they resorted to instead is leveraging $HEX$ vulnerability in $HEX$ well-known virtualization product called VirtualBox $NUM$ $HEX$ product made by Oracle which is widely used by researchers to analyse malware 
VirtualBox driver version $NUM$ was released in June $NUM$ $NUM$ $NUM$ 
$NUM$ months later $NUM$ in August $NUM$ $NUM$ security researchers reported that its main driver component $NUM$ which is signed under the entity $NUM$ innotek Gmbh $NUM$ $NUM$ contained $HEX$ privilege escalation vulnerability 
In $HEX$ nutshell $NUM$ the VirtualBox software installs $HEX$ driver called VBoxDrv 
The driver is controlled with the Input/Ouput Control Codes $NUM$ 32-bit values called IOCTL $NUM$ passed along DeviceIoControl $NUM$ $NUM$ API 
$NUM$ of the documented transfer methods that the system uses to pass data between the caller of DeviceIoControl $NUM$ $NUM$ API and the driver itself is called METHODNEITHER 
As per MSDN documentation $NUM$ METHODNEITHER is $HEX$ special transfer type when Input/Output Request Packet $NUM$ IRP $NUM$ supplies the user-mode virtual addresses of the input and output buffers $NUM$ without validating or mapping them 
It is the responsibility of the driver to validate the addresses sent from user mode in order to make sure those addresses are valid usermode addresses 
The source code of the vulnerable driver $NUM$ shown below $NUM$ demonstrates how the integer value of the rc variable is first derived from the input parameters pDevObj $NUM$ device object $NUM$ and pIrp $NUM$ request packet $NUM$ 
Next $NUM$ that integer value is written into the UserBuffer $NUM$ an arbitrary address $NUM$ pointed by the input parameter pIrp $NUM$ request packet $NUM$ 
This variable is used within the function SepInitializeCodeIntegrity $NUM$ $NUM$ $NUM$ implemented within CI.dll 's function CiInitialize $NUM$ $NUM$ and imported by the NT core $NUM$ ntoskrnl.exe $NUM$ 
These exploits are bundled within the dropper in its resource section as executable files 
As seen from the check-in logs found within $NUM$ of the recent samples $NUM$ the time span covers almost $NUM$ years from January $NUM$ till December $NUM$ $NUM$ which is aligned with the first reports of Agent.BTZ

From $HEX$ technical perspective $NUM$ Snake demonstrates $NUM$ very different approaches to the task of building $HEX$ cyber-espionage toolkit 
The complexity of the usermode-centric approach is on par with Rustock rootkit $NUM$ it uses similar techniques 
It 's an old well-polished technology that evolved over the years and demonstrated its resilience and survivability under the stress of security counter- measures 
The complexity of the kernel-centric architecture of Snake is quite unique 
This architecture is designed to grant Snake as much flexibility as possible 
We expect much more will $HEX$ uncovered by researchers in the coming weeks as the capabilities of this operation are further fleshed out

Operation Arachnophobia consists of an apparent targeted exploitation campaign $NUM$ dating back to early $NUM$ $NUM$ using the BITTERBUG malware family and seemingly directed against entities involved in India-Pakistan issues 
Research later identified that $HEX$ Pakistan-based VPSNOC representative had $HEX$ social network affiliation with $HEX$ Tranchulas employee as well as apparent affiliations with the Anonymous and AntiSec movements 
After the August $NUM$ $NUM$ $NUM$ blog $NUM$ Tranchulas provided TCIRT and the media an official statement and explanation of BITTERBUG activity $NUM$ however $NUM$ this explanation contained discrepancies 
The TCIRT addressed some of these discrepancies with Tranchulas personnel $NUM$ who were unresponsive $NUM$ increasing our suspicion of the activity 
We later observed BITTERBUG activity following August $NUM$ with subtle changes that further generalized debug paths

Emdivi allows the remote attacker executing the commands to send the results back to the command-and-control $NUM$ $HEX$ $NUM$ $HEX$ $NUM$ server through HTTP 
The malware adds extra words to the version number and then $NUM$ based on this $NUM$ generates $HEX$ hash $NUM$ which it uses as an encryption key 
Type T employs techniques to protect itself from security vendors or network administrators

Analysis of capabilities $NUM$ We found that the spyware has $HEX$ modular design $NUM$ and can download additional modules from $HEX$ command $NUM$ control $NUM$ $HEX$ $NUM$ $HEX$ $NUM$ server $NUM$ including password cap- ture $NUM$ from over $NUM$ applications $NUM$ and recording of screenshots $NUM$ Skype chat $NUM$ file transfers $NUM$ and input from the computer 's micro- phone and webcam 
To exfiltrate data back to the $HEX$ $NUM$ $HEX$ server $NUM$ $HEX$ module encrypts and writes it to disk in $HEX$ special folder 
The spyware period- ically probes this folder for files that match $HEX$ certain naming convention $NUM$ then sends them to the $HEX$ $NUM$ $HEX$ server 
It then over- writes the files $NUM$ renames them several times $NUM$ and deletes them $NUM$ in an apparent effort to frustrate forensic analysis 
Analysis of encryption $NUM$ Because the malware employed myriad known anti-debugging and anti-analysis techniques $NUM$ it thwarted our attempts to attach debuggers 
We found that FinSpy encrypts data using $HEX$ custom imple- mentation of AES-256-CBC 
The $NUM$ byte AES key and $NUM$ byte $NUM$ are generated by repeatedly reading the low-order-4-bytes of the Windows clock 
The key and IV are encrypted using an em- $HEX$ RSA-2048 public key $NUM$ and stored in the same file as the data 
Finally $NUM$ FinSpy 's wire protocol for $HEX$ $NUM$ $HEX$ commu- nication uses the same type of encryption $NUM$ and thus is subject to the same brute force attack on AES keys 
$HEX$ $NUM$ $HEX$ server $NUM$ The samples communicated with $NUM$ $NUM$ which belongs to $HEX$ subscriber of Batelco $NUM$ Bahrain 's main ISP 
We then infected the VM with FinSpy and allowed it to connect to the Bahrain $HEX$ $NUM$ $HEX$ server 
In an IP spy attack $NUM$ the attacker aims to discover the IP address of $HEX$ victim who is typically the opera- tor of $HEX$ pseudonymous social media or e-mail account 
The at- tacker sends the pseudonymous account $HEX$ link to $HEX$ webpage or an e-mail containing an embedded remote image $NUM$ using $NUM$ of many freely-available services 
When the victim clicks on the link or opens the e-mail $NUM$ their IP address is revealed to the at- tacker

Unfortunately $NUM$ several well-known attacks can $HEX$ used to achieve large-scale monitoring $NUM$ including DNS hijacking $NUM$ BGP hijacking $NUM$ and ARP hijacking in IDC 
In this context $NUM$ DNS hijacking is done to subvert the resolution of Domain Name System $NUM$ DNS $NUM$ queries through modifying the behavior of DNS servers so that they serve fake DNS information 
Attackers successfully compromised many DNS servers $NUM$ including the ones from Google and Godaddy 
By DNS hijacking $NUM$ attackers can effectively access all the traffic to $HEX$ servers 
BGP hijacking takes over groups of IP addresses $NUM$ corrupting Internet routing tables by breaking BGP sessions or injecting fake BGP information 
This enables attackers to monitor all traffic to specific IPs 
ARP hijacking $NUM$ or spoofing $NUM$ in IDC is done to hijack the traffic to the $HEX$ server in the IDC where the $HEX$ server locates through fake ARP packets 
Attackers may rent servers close to the target servers $NUM$ and use fake ARP packets to direct all the traffic to go through the hijacking servers first for monitoring and hijacking 
ARP hijacking is $HEX$ well-known approach used in network attacks 
Using the large-scale traffic intercepted from the above methods $NUM$ attackers can iden- tify potential victims based on information leakage such as GPS location described in Sec- tion $NUM$ 
After that $NUM$ they can inject exploits only into the targeted traffic to launch further attacks

Privilege escalation is $HEX$ category of techniques that describe the process of going from $HEX$ less privileged user on $HEX$ compromised computer to $HEX$ more privileged user 
This increase in privileges allows for the attacker to gain access to privleged areas of the operating system as well as to infect other computers on the target network 
PrivEsc is $HEX$ compiled exploit $NUM$ which leverages the vulnerability commonly referred to as KiTrap0D $NUM$ CVE-2010-0232 $NUM$ 
The exploit allows for escalation of privileges on unpatched Windows operating systems from an unprivileged user to kernel-level privilege 
Pivoting is the process of leveraging access from $NUM$ compromised computer in order to gain access to additional systems on the target network 
This can involve launching attacks from the compromised computer $NUM$ or simply abusing access once it has been gained 
$HEX$ very common method of pivoting on $HEX$ predominantly Windows operating system based network is to extract domain credentials which have been used on the compromised computer from $HEX$ credential cache 
There are $HEX$ few well-known tools which are capable of doing this given sufficient privileges on the infected host 
$NUM$ similar applications were developed by Operation Cleaver in order automate the execution of Mimikatz 
When executed $NUM$ they determine which version of Mimikatz to use based on whether the computer 's version of Windows is 32-bit or 64-bit 
zhMimikatz executes the correct version of Mimikatz for the current system $NUM$ and parses the results for any cached credentials 
The only external difference is that MimikatzWrapper also logs these results to res.txt in the executing directory 
This can make it useful for tools like the PVZ tool chain and Csext to execute with logged results $NUM$ Once an attacker has credentials extracted from the cache $NUM$ whether in hash form or in plaintext form $NUM$ PsExec can $HEX$ used to run commands on any other computer which accepts those domain credentials 
If this technique is combined with cached credential dumping $NUM$ it can $HEX$ used to jump from computer to computer on $HEX$ compromised network 
Net Crawler utilizes $HEX$ cached credential dumping technique along with PsExec in order to worm throughout $HEX$ network $NUM$ collecting any and all credentials that it can extract from credential caches 
It starts by first extracting cached credentials from the infected computer 's cache 
Once this is complete $NUM$ it then continues to scan $HEX$ set of configured IP addresses on the local subnet to determine which IP addresses have SMB related ports open 
Then an iterative methodology is applied to brute forcing each SMB enabled target with each credential that was extracted from the cache 
When $HEX$ positive result has been achieved $NUM$ it will create $HEX$ copy of itself with $HEX$ modified configuration stored as $HEX$ PE resource $NUM$ then send and execute the copy utilizing PsExec 
This copy repeats the behavior of the original $NUM$ but with already discovered credentials as well as newly discovered ones on the newly infected host 
MS08-067 is $HEX$ vulnerability in Microsoft Windows made popular by the Conficker worm which can $HEX$ exploited by $HEX$ specially crafted packet to the operating system 's RPC network interface 
Jasus is an ARP cache poisoner developed by the Operation Cleaver team 
The primary positive attribute of Jasus is its poor detection ratio by the antivirus industry

It also has $HEX$ remotely installable trojan named Abel $NUM$ which enables some of its functionality on $HEX$ remote target

Exfiltration is the process of moving information to an external site 
In this context $NUM$ it is the process of stealing information without being detected 
Operation Cleaver has $HEX$ strong focus on stealing confidential/privileged information $NUM$ and they have utilized $HEX$ few methods in order to facilitate this objective

Its main functionality allows for $HEX$ client and server communication channel $NUM$ allowing for information to $HEX$ transported over the network simply 
NetCat has an option when being compiled to enable or disable the ability for NetCat to execute $HEX$ command after the connection is established 
This feature can $HEX$ abused to enable $HEX$ reverse connecting shell $NUM$ which can $HEX$ used to remotely control $HEX$ target 
The Operation Cleaver team was observed attempting to use NetCat to exfiltrate information as well as use it as $HEX$ reverse connecting shell 
Its main purpose is to create $HEX$ channel that is capable of transporting information over the network 
The changes made in zhCat allow for this information to $HEX$ transferred with inline obfuscation and/ or encryption 
This makes it more difficult to detect that privileged information is being exfiltrated 
This makes the traffic between zhCat instances look like benign HTTP traffic 
If we observe the network communications during this transfer $NUM$ we can see the following HTTP POST request 
On the server side $NUM$ we can see our message has been received $NUM$ If stricter egress filtering is enabled $NUM$ the attackers can use zhCat to also XOR encrypt the traffic with $HEX$ shared key 
The following is the key used for XOR encryption $NUM$ The $doubleSlash$ represents hex character $HEX$ $NUM$ which is $HEX$ new line character 
An attacker could set up $HEX$ server instance of zhCat with the following command in order to enable both HTTP and XOR obfuscation $NUM$ The client instance could then $HEX$ invoked with the following command $NUM$ Once again $NUM$ information can $HEX$ supplied via standard input

On the server side $NUM$ we can see this information being received $NUM$ zhCat has $HEX$ variety of other features such as port mirroring as well as traffic redirecting 
Operation Cleaver uses PLink to forward local RDP ports to remote SSH servers 
This allows them to easily connect to RDP servers inside the networks of their victims 
These RDP connections can $HEX$ used to exfiltrate information visually $NUM$ as well as to remotely control the computers hosting the RDP servers

SOAP is $HEX$ sub-protocol communicated via HTTP 
In relation to Operation Cleaver $NUM$ it is used as the command and control protocol for TinyZBot $NUM$ which was the preferred backdoor $NUM$ and underwent long-term development

It is likely that SOAP was used because it is simple to implement in $HEX$ $NUM$ $NUM$ and has the $HEX$ benefit of blending in with other benign HTTP traffic

Hikit consists of at least $NUM$ generations of malware that provides basic RAT functionality 
The first generation of Hikit $NUM$ referred to as $NUM$ Gen $NUM$ $NUM$ $NUM$ operates as $HEX$ server and requires an externally exposed network interface in order for an attacker to access the victim machine 
The second generation of Hikit $NUM$ referred to as $NUM$ Gen $NUM$ $NUM$ $NUM$ uses the more traditional client model and beacons out to an attacker 's $HEX$ server 
While the communication models shifted dramatically between Gen $NUM$ and Gen $NUM$ $NUM$ both generations of Hikit retain the same basic RAT function consisting of remote command shell $NUM$ file management $NUM$ network proxy and port forwarding 
Both Gen $NUM$ and Gen $NUM$ sub-families of Hikit consist of $HEX$ main DLL $NUM$ referred to as $NUM$ the DLL $NUM$ $NUM$ that contains the RAT functionality $NUM$ $HEX$ kernel driver $NUM$ referred to as $NUM$ the Driver $NUM$ $NUM$ with Gen $NUM$ also employs an additional component $NUM$ $HEX$ loader executable 
The Gen $NUM$ Driver listens to network traffic arriving at the local network interface and waits for $HEX$ specific trigger string 
The Gen $NUM$ Driver is $HEX$ simpler system driver that acts as $HEX$ rootkit to hide processes $NUM$ registry keys and network connections associated with Gen $NUM$ activity on the victim 's system 
In Gen $NUM$ $NUM$ the communication between the infected machine and the attacker is encrypted using an XOR mask 
The DLL will send $HEX$ legitimate SSL certificate as $HEX$ means to disrupt heuristic IDS sensors that look for encrypted traffic 
The Driver intercepts any and all network communication that traverses the Windows network stack and potentially removes the data from the network stack under very specific conditions 
The purpose of this behavior is to allow the DLL to interact with the network without utilizes the WinSock API which could potentially reveal the presence of Hikit

In both architectures there is $HEX$ kernel mode driver installed and $HEX$ usermode DLL injected by the driver into the system processes 
With this architecture $NUM$ the Snake driver is mainly used to load the DLL module into the usermode processes $NUM$ and then use that module for the communications 
When first executed $NUM$ the driver creates device named $doubleSlash$ with $HEX$ symbolic link $doubleSlash$ 
This device is used for userland/kernel communications 
Next $NUM$ it drops $HEX$ DLL into the $NUM$ windows $NUM$ directory $NUM$ the DLL is carried in the body of the driver as $HEX$ binary chunk with XOR $HEX$ applied on top of it $NUM$ so the driver decrypts it first

Another set of hooks it sets is designed to hide the presence of the Snake components on the system $NUM$ The driver then watches for all userland processes to see if they load any web pages

$NUM$ Once the task of communication with $HEX$ $NUM$ $HEX$ is delegated to the pipe server $NUM$ it will start communicating with the $HEX$ $NUM$ $HEX$ $NUM$ bypassing the host-based firewalls that keep an infected system process in $HEX$ white-list 
The reason behind the pipes usage is to 'legitimise $NUM$ the outbound web requests $NUM$ forcing them to originate from the host firewall- friendly system services 
In order to switch into that mode $NUM$ $HEX$ dedicated thread is spawned to listen for IPC messages received through the pipes 
The memory pipes used by Snake are named as $NUM$ Apart from GET $NUM$ POST requests $NUM$ the pipe clients $NUM$ infected usermode processes $NUM$ may also ask the pipe server to perform other operations on their behalf $NUM$ such as saving data into $HEX$ temporary file $NUM$ copy $NUM$ delete files $NUM$ save configuration data into the registry under the aforementioned ShellCore value

To delegate different types of tasks $NUM$ the clients send messages to the pipe server using the following task identification headers $NUM$ The usermode component of Snake communicates with its kernel-mode driver via $HEX$ device called $doubleSlash$ $NUM$ created under kernel as $doubleSlash$ $NUM$

The ability to update the driver and then rely on its communication capabilities means that the components of Snake are flexible $NUM$ making possible the existence of the hybrid $NUM$ kernel-centric and usermode-centric $NUM$ architectures 
For example $NUM$ the virtual partitions are used by kernel-centric Snake variants $NUM$ where the kernel-mode driver is responsible for the communications

The analysed 32-bit dropper creates $HEX$ driver in the following location $NUM$ However $NUM$ different samples may use $HEX$ different path and driver file name 
The registration is ensured with creation of the following registry entries $NUM$ The driver then flags the following events with the notification purposes $NUM$ The rootkit then places $HEX$ number of the hooks 
The first API it hooks is IoCreateDevice $NUM$ $NUM$ 
The installed hook handler calls the original API and then checks if the name of the device is netbt or $HEX$

In order to hide its components $NUM$ the driver hooks the following APIs $NUM$ For example $NUM$ the hook handlers of the registry-related APIs will block access to the registry entries that contain the name of the driver 
In $NUM$ example $NUM$ the rootkit blocks access to registry entries that contain the strings $NUM$ Ultra3 $NUM$ and $NUM$ ~ROOT $NUM$ 
The ZwReadFile $NUM$ $NUM$ hook handler will block access to the home directory where the rootkit keeps its file

The ZwClose $NUM$ $NUM$ hook handler is used to inject the DLL module into the userland processes 
The hook handler for ZwTerminateProcess $NUM$ $NUM$ checks if the process being shut down is svchost.exe 
If so $NUM$ it considers it to $HEX$ $HEX$ system shutdown $NUM$ so it unloads its usermode DLL and deactivates its own network drivers $NUM$ just like it does when its ZwShutdownSystem $NUM$ $NUM$ hook handler gets invoked 
The ObOpenObjectByName $NUM$ $NUM$ hook is designed to hide the presence of its virtual partitions $NUM$ described later $NUM$ 
To encrypt data stored on its virtual partitions $NUM$ the driver sets $HEX$ hook for another API $NUM$ To re-infect the usermode process svchost.exe and to re-enable its network drivers $NUM$ the rootkit hooks these APIs $NUM$ Snake then proceeds to the task of deep packet inspection and modification 
In order to accomplish it $NUM$ it registers $HEX$ callout driver for Windows Filtering Platform $NUM$ WFP $NUM$ $NUM$ an architecture first introduced with Windows Vista and nowadays normally used by antivirus and/or intrusion detection systems to inspect/block malicious traffic 
Snake sets filters at the layers FWPMLAYERSTREAMV4 and FWPMLAYERALEFLOWESTABLISHEDV4 in the TCP/ IP stack $NUM$ so that its callout driver is notified whenever $HEX$ TCP connection is established by $HEX$ browser 
When that happens $NUM$ the rootkit triggers an event named $doubleSlash$ 
When the data arrives $NUM$ it is intercepted with the FwpsCopyStreamDataToBuffer0 $NUM$ $NUM$ API $NUM$ and then scanned for the presence of the hidden commands from $HEX$ $NUM$ $HEX$ 
The driver inspects bidirectional network data on $HEX$ per stream basis $NUM$ as it 's located right on the stream data path 
An ability to manipulate data streams is provided with the packet injection logic below $NUM$ allowing Snake to covertly insert traffic destined to its $HEX$ $NUM$ $HEX$ servers $NUM$ In order to qualify as $HEX$ browser $NUM$ the usermode process must have any of the following names $NUM$ In addition to WFP $NUM$ Snake also hooks the Transport Driver Interface $NUM$ TDI $NUM$ network routines by setting itself up as $HEX$ TDI filter driver 
Being registered as $HEX$ TDI driver on the device stack $NUM$ Snake hooks TCP calls 
This way it intercepts all requests along with their parameters via IRP $NUM$ IO request package $NUM$ hooks 
By 'sniffing $NUM$ all the requests $NUM$ it can now inspect the traffic $NUM$ looking for and then parsing GET $NUM$ POST HTTP requests and also SMTP communications $NUM$ in order to distinguish commands addressed to itself 
If the rootkit detects that the OS version is pre-Vista $NUM$ e.g 
Windows XP $NUM$ or Windows Server $NUM$ $NUM$ e.g 
Windows Server $NUM$ $NUM$ $NUM$ it will invoke FwpsStreamInjectAsync0 $NUM$ $NUM$ API in order to generate outbound requests 
Whenever the client establishes connections $NUM$ the TDI driver will also 'pulse $NUM$ the $doubleSlash$ event $NUM$ just like the WPF driver 's component of it $NUM$ in order to notify the userland service about the event
